inaugurated in 1962 (S. Molfesis, 
Th. Papagiannis). Its exterior 
side combines modern and 
classical elements with wings 
added on the sides. It connects 
Thessaloniki with the rest of 
Greece, the Balkans and Istanbul; 
it is also the bus terminus 
towards most of the city areas. 
This will be the location of the 
west metro line terminus under 
construction in Thessaloniki.
2.2  Old Railway Station.
It was built in 1894 near the 
harbour (Old Station Street) 
in the neoclassical style, 
and it gradually connected 
Thessaloniki with Skopje, 
Belgrade, Monastir and 
Constantinople (modern-day 
Istanbul). Today it', 'filochias

ottoman fountain.
11	\x07BYZANTINE BATHS  
(KULE KAFE)
It is located on Romfei Sq. (see 
p. 43) in Ano Poli and it is the 
only surviving Byzantine bath 
house, a domed 13th c. building 
made of brick, which was 
open to the public until 1940.

UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
During the Ottoman period it 
was named Kule Hamam and 
was divided in two (male and 
female section).
12 	\x07HOSIOS DAVID  
(MONI LATOMOU)
Moni Latomou [Latomou 
Monastery] has a huge 
archaeological and historical 
value, since it is an early type 
of a cross-in-square domed 
church. Its construction dates 
back to the 5th or 6th c. and 
it is believed to have been 
built by Theodora, daughter 
of the Byzantine emperor 
Maximilianus, who had been 
baptised a Christian. The 
monastery was dedicated to 
Hosios David [Saint David] in 
1921. Especially noteworthy 
are the mosaic depictions 
on the ceiling which show 
the Vision of Ezekiel and 
are contemporary to the 
construction of the monastery; 
the later ones of the 12th, 13th 
and 14th c. are also great art 
specimens of the Komnenian 
period. There is a surviving 
minaret entrance built in the 
16th c. when the church was 
converted into a mosque. The', 'thex. 
In 1430 it was converted into 
a mosque and was named 
Kazancilar Camii.
3 	\x07
ACHEIROPOIITOS 
CHURCH
It was founded in the second 
half of the 5th c. on the site 
of the roman public baths 
and it was dedicated to 
Panagia (Virgin Mary). It is a 
three-aisled, timber-roofed 
basilica with a narthex and a 
gallery. The nave is separated 
by the side aisles with 
colonnades of Theodosian-
style pillars and impost 
capitals made of marble 
as is made the floor of the 
nave. The preserved mosaic 
decorations date to the 5th 
c. whereas the murals on the 
south aisle date to the 13th 
c. After the city was captured 
by the Turks, this was the 
first church to be turned into 
a mosque. In 1922-1923 it 
housed refugees from Asia 
Minor and in 1939 Christian 
worship was once again 
practiced in it.
4 	\x07
AGIA SOFIA CHURCH 
[or ΗAGIA SOPHIA]
It was built in the mid-7th c.  
on the ruins of a 5th c. basilica, 
as a copy of Hagia Sophia 
[Holy Wisdom of God] in 
Constantinople, and is one  
of the most important early-

Christian monuments in the 
Orthodox world. It is a cross-

be the Metropolitan Church 
(Cathedral) until 1523 when it 
was converted into a mosque; 
it was restored to Christian 
worship after 1912.', ' [ROTONTA]
This impressive round building 
lies on the route connecting 
the triumphal arch of Galerius 
(Kamara, see p. 37) and the 
Palace of Galerius (see p. 29). 
It has a diameter of 24.5 m. 
and its gigantic dome is 30 
m. high. It was built in 306 
AD by Galerius, probably as a 
temple of Zeus or Kaveiros or 
as a mausoleum; in the 5th c. 
it was converted into a church 
dedicated to the Holy Bodiless 
Powers. The 5th c. outstanding 
preserved mosaics impress 
with their variety of themes, 
their naturalistic rendering, 
the colour diversity and the 
brilliance of the gold and 
silver tesserae. In 1591 it was 
turned into a mosque when a 
towering minaret was added, 
which survives today. In the 
square, next to Rotunda, lies 
the small church of Agios  
Georgios [St. George] whence 
the monument took its

7 	\x07AGIOS PANTELEIMONAS 
CHURCH
It is on Iasonidou st., pretty 
close to Rotunda. According 
to certain scholars, this 
was the main church of 
the Monastery of Kyr Isaac 
or Theotokos Perivleptos, 
founded by Jacob, the 
Metropolitan Bishop of 
Thessaloniki (1295-1314). 
It is a tetrastyle cross-in-
square domed church with a 
surrounding portico ending 
to the east in two chapels. 
During the Turkish Occupation 
it was changed into a mosque 
under the name Ishakiye 
Camii (the mosque of Isaac). 
Remaining murals date to 
the 13th – 14th c. and depict 
saints and prelates as well  
the Virgin Mary.
8 	\x07
AGIOS DIMITRIOS 
CHURCH
It is the best known Byzantine 
church of the town as Agios 
Dimitrios [St. Demetrius] is 
Thessaloniki’s patron saint. It 
was built during the 7th c. on 
the ruins of a 5th c. Basilica and 
in 1493 it was converted into 
a mosque. It was destroyed 
in 1917 by the fire but it was 
restored and reopened in 
1948. It is a five-aisle transept 
basilica with a women’s gallery 
and a narthex. The sculpted 
decorative motifs originate 
from the 5th c. basilica and 
other buildings and this 
explains their variety; equally 
interesting are the capitals (5th 
and 6th c.). The mosaics found 
on the west side date to the 
5', ' a major Greek 
architect, and it was 
inaugurated in 1962. Inspired 
by the ancient Greek Revival 
Architectural style, it is 
considered as one of the most 
typical examples of modernist 
architectural design in Greece. 
An annex was added in 1980 
and in 2003 the museum  
was extensively remodelled  
to accommodate contemporary 
needs. There are rooms for 
periodic exhibitions, events 
and educational programmes, 
a café and a shop (see p.70  
for museum exhibits).  
1.7  Museum of Byzantine 
Culture.
It was built during the 
years 1989 – 1993, following 
the designs of architect K. 
Krokos. It combines elements 
of modernism and Greek 
architectural tradition and it 
is considered one of the best 
contemporary constructions 
meant for public use in Greece.  
In 2001 it was declared a 
listed historic monument and  
a work of art. Inside there is  
a small amphitheatre, a café-
restaurant and a wing for 
hosting periodic exhibitions 
(see p. 71 for museum 
exhibits). The adjacent 
building is the new Town Hall 
(inaugurated in 2009); at the 
back there is a park (formerly 
named Pedion Areos, a section 
of an old military camp), with 
a playground, a small lake and

It is the city’s oldest cultural

THE ROMAN FORUM 
MUSEUM
Small yet very interesting, 
this museum was inaugurated 
in 2010. A narrative of local 
excavations and information 
on the museum’s building 
stages is on display in the 
vestibule; in the main hall, 
visitors will see a depiction 
of the area’s history from the 
Hellenistic years until the 4th 
c. AD. Other exhibits of great 
interest are the Hellenistic 
Bathhouse, the ancient brothel, 
and the fountain associated 
with the Stoa of the Statuettes 
(Las Incantadas). There are 
also finds related to the period 
from the Turkish Occupation 
until the 1917 fire. Next to 
exhibited items, there are 
descriptive texts and photos.
MUSEUM OF BYZANTINE 
CULTURE
It is considered one of the 
best museums in Greece and 
ranks high among its peers 
across the globe, offering 
a detailed picture of the 
Byzantine culture. Among 
the 2,900 masterpieces of 
exhibits, there are murals, 
mosaics, icons, marble 
architectural members, whole 
Early Christian tombs, church 
vessels, items of personal 
dress, as well as objects of 
everyday use and tools used

Small yet very', ' and the White Tower (see p. 
24) were built during that period. 
In the following centuries, the 
Turks completed reinforcement 
works in various places. The 
wall inscriptions describe the 
interventions and restorations 
that took place over time. The 
walls followed the shape of an 
irregular trapezium and ended 
to the west in Vardariou Tower 
(see p. 59) and to the east in 
the White Tower (see p. 24), 
reaching a total length of 7 km. 
After 1870, demolition of the 
seafront walls as well as of parts 
of the western and eastern walls 
began, in order to sanitise the 
plains and also to expand the 
city. Today there are 3 remaining 
km of city walls (mainly on Ano 
Poli, see p. 42); their height 
ranges from 8.30 to 10.50 m. 
and their width may measure 
up to 4.50 m, making them 
an impressive monument and 
one of great archaeological and 
cultural value.

reference_contexts: ["UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS Thessaloniki has been one of the first towns to know the Christian religion by the Apostle Paul; during the Byzantine period it used to be the second most important city of the empire (co-reigning city) after Constantinople. At that time (4th – 15th c.), Christian monuments and churches were constructed in the town, and these make up a diachronic typology with a decisive influence on the entire Byzantine world. The following early-Christian and Byzantine monuments of the town are considered to be excellent specimens of the Byzantine church-building and art, and for this reason UNESCO declared them to be World Heritage Monuments, in 1988. A tour across this unique open-air Byzantine museum is truly a special experience. 1 \x07HOLY TWELVE APOSTLES CHURCH One of the town’s oldest churches was built in 1310 – 1314 under the sponsorship of Patriarch Nephon I. It used to be a katholicon [main church] of a monastery dedicated to Theotokos [Mother of God] as shown by the mural depicting Theotokos and the Founder, as well as by the iconography on the aisle with images of the Holy Virgin’s life. Out of the original monastery complex, -apart from the katholicon – there remain the NIKIS NIKIS GERMANOU SVOLOU IASONIDOU TSIMISKI VAS. response:
### Notable Byzantine Monuments in Thessaloniki

Thessaloniki, a city rich in history and culture, is home to several significant Byzantine monuments that reflect its architectural and religious heritage. Here are some of the most notable ones:

#### 1. **Agios Dimitrios Church**
Agios Dimitrios Church is perhaps the most renowned Byzantine church in Thessaloniki, dedicated to the city's patron saint, St. Demetrius. Originally built in the 7th century on the ruins of a 5th-century basilica, it showcases a five-aisle transept basilica design. The church has undergone various transformations, including its conversion into a mosque during the Ottoman period. Its historical significance is highlighted by its decorative motifs and mosaics, which date back to different periods [Data: Entities (439); Relationships (161)].

#### 2. **Hagia Sophia**
The Hagia Sophia in Thessaloniki is a remarkable example of Byzantine architecture, built in the mid-7th century. It was constructed on the site of an earlier basilica and is known for its cross-domed design, resembling the famous Hagia Sophia in Istanbul. This church served as the Metropolitan Church until it was converted into a mosque in the 16th century, and it remains a significant religious site today [Data: Entities (424); Relationships (140)].

#### 3. **Rotunda**
Originally built as a mausoleum for Emperor Galerius in the early 4th century, the Rotunda was later converted into a church and then a mosque. Its impressive dome and large circular structure make it a unique architectural feat. The interior features stunning mosaics from the 5th century, showcasing the artistic achievements of the Byzantine era [Data: Sources (18)].

#### 4. **Byzantine Baths**
The Byzantine Baths, also known as Kule Kafe, are the only surviving bathhouse from the Byzantine period in Thessaloniki. Dating back to the 13th century, this domed structure provides insight into the social and cultural practices of the time. It was open to the public until 1940 and remains a significant historical site [Data: Sources (11)].

#### 5. **Moni Vlatadon**
Moni Vlatadon is a historic monastery located in the upper part of Thessaloniki. It is recognized for its architectural significance and is included in the UNESCO Byzantine Monuments list. The monastery offers a glimpse into the monastic life during the Byzantine era and is a peaceful retreat for visitors [Data: Sources (183)].

### Conclusion
These monuments not only represent the rich Byzantine heritage of Thessaloniki but also serve as vital links to the city's past. Each site offers unique insights into the architectural styles, religious practices, and cultural influences that have shaped Thessaloniki over the centuries. Visitors to the city can explore these historical treasures, gaining a deeper appreciation for its diverse history and cultural landscape [Data: Entities (424, 1257, 439, 481, 3); Relationships (1299, 1300, 2398, 2399, +more)].
reference: Thessaloniki is home to several notable Byzantine monuments, including the Holy Twelve Apostles Church, which was built between 1310 and 1314 and served as the main church of a monastery dedicated to Theotokos. These monuments are recognized for their architectural significance and were declared UNESCO World Heritage Monuments in 1988.

period. There is a surviving

At that time (4th – 15th c.), Christian monuments and churches were constructed in the town, and these make up a diachronic typology with a decisive influence on the entire Byzantine world. The following early-Christian and Byzantine monuments of the town are considered to be excellent specimens of the Byzantine church-building and art, and for this reason UNESCO declared them to be World Heritage Monuments, in 1988. response:
## Understanding Byzantine Church-Building

Byzantine church-building refers to the architectural style and construction practices that emerged during the Byzantine Empire, particularly from the 4th to the 15th centuries. This style is characterized by its grand domes, intricate mosaics, and the use of cross-in-square designs, which were intended to create a sense of heavenly space within the church. The architectural elements often included a combination of basilicas and centralized plans, showcasing the artistic and engineering advancements of the time.

In Thessaloniki, Byzantine church-building is particularly significant due to the city's historical role as a major center of the Byzantine Empire. The city was home to numerous churches that exemplify this architectural style, many of which have been recognized as UNESCO World Heritage Sites. These churches not only serve as places of worship but also as cultural landmarks that reflect the rich history and religious traditions of the region.

## Importance in Thessaloniki

Thessaloniki is renowned for its impressive collection of Byzantine churches, which are integral to the city's identity and cultural heritage. Notable examples include the **Agios Dimitrios Church**, the most significant Byzantine church in the city, and the **Agia Sofia Church**, which was modeled after the famous Hagia Sophia in Constantinople. These churches are characterized by their unique architectural features, such as the five-aisle transept basilica design of Agios Dimitrios and the cross-domed structure of Agia Sofia, which highlight the artistic achievements of the Byzantine era [Data: Reports (100); Entities (439, 441)].

The preservation of these churches is crucial for maintaining the historical narrative of Thessaloniki. They serve as a testament to the city's evolution through various historical epochs, including periods of religious transformation and cultural exchange. The churches not only attract tourists and scholars but also foster a sense of local pride and continuity in the community's religious practices [Data: Relationships (161, 162); Entities (441)].

In summary, Byzantine church-building is a vital aspect of Thessaloniki's architectural and cultural landscape. It represents the city's historical significance as a center of Byzantine culture and religion, contributing to its identity as a vibrant hub of history and heritage in Greece. The churches stand as enduring symbols of the city's past, enriching the experience of both locals and visitors alike.
reference: Byzantine church-building refers to the construction of Christian monuments and churches during the Byzantine period, particularly in Thessaloniki, which was the second most important city of the empire after Constantinople. This period, spanning from the 4th to the 15th century, saw the creation of significant Christian monuments that have a decisive influence on the entire Byzantine world. These monuments are recognized for their architectural and artistic value, leading UNESCO to declare them World Heritage Monuments in 1988.

At that time (4th – 15th c.), Christian monuments and churches were constructed in the town, and these make up a diachronic typology with a decisive influence on the entire Byzantine world. The following early-Christian and Byzantine monuments of the town are considered to be excellent specimens of the Byzantine church-building and art, and for this reason UNESCO declared them to be World Heritage Monuments, in 1988. response:
## The Role of Constantinople in the Byzantine Empire

Constantinople, known today as Istanbul, served as the capital of the Byzantine Empire and was a pivotal center for political, cultural, and economic activities throughout its history. Established by Emperor Constantine the Great in 330 AD, the city was strategically located on the Bosporus Strait, making it a vital hub for trade and military operations. Its geographical position allowed for control over key trade routes between Europe and Asia, which significantly contributed to the empire's wealth and influence.

### Political Significance

As the capital, Constantinople was the seat of the Byzantine emperors and the administrative heart of the empire. The city housed the imperial palace, where the emperor and his court resided, and it was the center of governance and law. The political landscape of the Byzantine Empire was heavily influenced by the events that unfolded in Constantinople, including the various military campaigns and diplomatic relations with neighboring states. The city's fortifications, particularly the famous walls built by Theodosius II, provided a formidable defense against invasions, allowing the empire to thrive for centuries [Data: Entities (65); Relationships (1582)].

### Cultural and Religious Center

Constantinople was not only a political stronghold but also a cultural and religious epicenter. The city was renowned for its magnificent churches, such as the Hagia Sophia, which symbolized the architectural and artistic achievements of the Byzantine Empire. It served as a melting pot of cultures, where Greek, Roman, and Eastern influences converged, leading to a rich tapestry of art, literature, and philosophy. The city was also a major center for Christianity, with the Patriarch of Constantinople being one of the highest-ranking figures in the Eastern Orthodox Church. This religious significance further solidified the city's role as a cultural beacon in the region [Data: Reports (162); Entities (16)].

### Economic Hub

Economically, Constantinople was a bustling metropolis that facilitated trade across the Mediterranean and beyond. The city's markets were filled with goods from various parts of the world, including silk, spices, and precious metals. The wealth generated from trade allowed the Byzantine Empire to maintain a strong military and support its extensive bureaucracy. The city's strategic location also made it a target for various conquests, leading to its eventual fall to the Ottoman Turks in 1453, which marked the end of the Byzantine Empire [Data: Entities (46); Relationships (1583)].

In summary, Constantinople played a crucial role in the Byzantine Empire as its capital, a center of culture and religion, and a hub of economic activity. Its historical significance continues to resonate today, reflecting the enduring legacy of the Byzantine Empire in world history.
reference: Constantinople was the most important city of the Byzantine Empire, serving as its capital and co-reigning city during the Byzantine period.

and also Jewish and western 
European influences, thus 
creating unique culinary 
combinations. Downtown (see 
p. 15-41), in Ano Poli (see p. 
42 - 49) and in the seaside 
suburbs and city outskirts (see 
p. 63 - 69), the traditional 
tavernas, ouzo restaurants and 
luxury restaurants highlight the 
local traditional gastronomy 
often creatively mixing it with 
gourmet tastes. 
Thessaloniki’s gastronomy 
can boast some pretty 
impressive delicacies 
[mezedes] such as gyro [slices 
of meat roasted on a spit] and 
souvlaki, patsa, a variety of 
soup, pies, Anatolian dishes 
(tzigerosarmades, giaprakia, 
gardoumpes, kebab etc), 
lake and sea fish, seafood 
delicacies (mussel pilaf, 
saganaki with shrimps, stuffed 
calamari etc). Confectionery 
is also an important part 
of local gastronomy and it 
features the renowned syrupy 
cakes and pastry originating 
from Istanbul (ekmek kadayifi, 
kazandibi, tulumba etc) the 
well-known bougatsa [filled 
either with cheese or with 
cream], galaktompoureko 
[a type of pastry filled with 
custard], and last but not least 
trigona Panoramatos [a cone-
shaped syrupy cream-filled puff 
pastry] (see p. 65). Koulouri 
Thessalonikis is also worthy 
of mention. It is a sesame-
covered piece of bread and 
an everyday snack for locals, 
which you can find in the 
morning hours sold by street 
vendors or at the', 'ations 
include singing and dancing 
throughout the entire day.

• October 26th – 28th: 
A three-day celebration 
commemorating the liberation 
of the city from the Turkish rule, 
and a religious feast in honour 
of Saint Demetrius [Agios 
Dimitrios], the patron saint of 
the city, on October 26th. A 
military parade takes place on 
October 28th to commemorate 
the beginning of Greek 
participation in World War II.
• Christmas:  
December 25th – 26th.
OTHER TRADITIONAL 
FESTIVALS
• Carnival: Carnival events last 
for 3 weeks and end on Shrove 
Monday. Celebrations are organised 
in many areas of the region.
• Pentecost: A feast celebrated 
50 days after Easter.

', ' kept its urban character and has 
remained a civic centre and the hub of that region. 
The city’s centuries-old multicultural history has been 
associated with great empires, as it has known the 
Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman Rule. The town was also 
greatly influenced by many ethnic and religious groups 
(Jews, Latins, Armenians and others) as well as Greeks 
from Constantinople, Pontus [modern-day northeastern 
Turkey] and Asia Minor [a.k.a. Anatolia]. The numerous 
monuments, dating to many historical periods, coexist in 
a singular and charming way and manifest Thessaloniki’s 
historical multicultural and cosmopolitan nature.

Nowadays, the historic capital -by right- of Macedonia, 
the land of Alexander the Great, has evolved into a modern 
and particularly charming metropolis. A multitide of 
monuments and cultural assets and the town’s traditional 
ways exist in harmony with the modern aspects and the 
high standard infrastructure, the carefree mood, the spirit 
of hospitality, the vitality of the locals – particularly the 
young – setting the pace of town life, the diversity of 
artistic events, the long list of choices for entertainment, 
the exceptional culinary tradition, and the fresh feel in 
the atmosphere, coming from the seafront, as', ' you will reach the very 
popular and absolutely beautiful 
beaches of Halkidiki (see p. 92).

reference_contexts: ["UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS Thessaloniki has been one of the first towns to know the Christian religion by the Apostle Paul; during the Byzantine period it used to be the second most important city of the empire (co-reigning city) after Constantinople. At that time (4th – 15th c.), Christian monuments and churches were constructed in the town, and these make up a diachronic typology with a decisive influence on the entire Byzantine world. The following early-Christian and Byzantine monuments of the town are considered to be excellent specimens of the Byzantine church-building and art, and for this reason UNESCO declared them to be World Heritage Monuments, in 1988. A tour across this unique open-air Byzantine museum is truly a special experience. 1 \x07HOLY TWELVE APOSTLES CHURCH One of the town’s oldest churches was built in 1310 – 1314 under the sponsorship of Patriarch Nephon I. It used to be a katholicon [main church] of a monastery dedicated to Theotokos [Mother of God] as shown by the mural depicting Theotokos and the Founder, as well as by the iconography on the aisle with images of the Holy Virgin’s life. Out of the original monastery complex, -apart from the katholicon – there remain the NIKIS NIKIS GERMANOU SVOLOU IASONIDOU TSIMISKI VAS. response:
## Holy Twelve Apostles Church: History and Significance

The **Holy Twelve Apostles Church** is one of the oldest and most significant churches in Thessaloniki, Greece. Built between **1310 and 1314**, it originally served as the main church of a monastery dedicated to Theotokos (Mother of God). This church is notable for its historical and architectural value, representing a key example of Byzantine architecture in the region [Data: Entities (67, 1280); Relationships (358, 1325)].

### Historical Context

The church was constructed under the sponsorship of **Patriarch Nephon I**, and it has played a vital role in the religious and cultural life of Thessaloniki. It is recognized as a **World Heritage Monument** by UNESCO due to its historical and architectural significance, showcasing the rich heritage of Byzantine church-building [Data: Entities (67); Relationships (63, 2398)].

Throughout its history, the Holy Twelve Apostles Church has undergone various transformations. It was originally part of a larger monastic complex, and although much of the original structure has been lost, the church itself remains a testament to the architectural style of the Byzantine era. The church features exquisite murals and iconography that depict various religious scenes, highlighting its artistic and historical importance [Data: Entities (67, 468); Relationships (66)].

### Cultural Significance

The Holy Twelve Apostles Church is not only a place of worship but also a significant cultural landmark in Thessaloniki. It contributes to the city's rich tapestry of religious and cultural institutions, which include various churches and synagogues that reflect the diverse heritage of the region. The church's location near the historical city walls and other significant landmarks enhances its importance within the urban landscape of Thessaloniki [Data: Entities (67, 403); Relationships (2417)].

The church is often included in cultural tours of Thessaloniki, attracting visitors interested in its historical and architectural features. It serves as a reminder of the city's long-standing Christian traditions and its role as a center of religious life throughout the centuries [Data: Entities (0, 67); Relationships (2301, 2302)].

### Conclusion

In summary, the Holy Twelve Apostles Church stands as a significant historical and cultural monument in Thessaloniki. Its rich history, architectural beauty, and role in the community make it a must-visit site for anyone exploring the city's diverse heritage. The church not only reflects the artistic achievements of the Byzantine period but also continues to be a vital part of Thessaloniki's religious landscape today [Data: Entities (67, 1280); Relationships (358, 1325)].
reference: The Holy Twelve Apostles Church is one of the oldest churches in Thessaloniki, built between 1310 and 1314 under the sponsorship of Patriarch Nephon I. It served as the main church of a monastery dedicated to Theotokos (Mother of God), which is evident from the mural depicting Theotokos and the Founder, as well as the iconography on the aisle illustrating the life of the Holy Virgin. The church is part of the early-Christian and Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki, which were recognized by UNESCO as World Heritage Monuments in 1988 due to their exceptional representation of Byzantine church-building and art. This makes a visit to the Holy Twelve Apostles Church a significant experience for those interested in the history and architecture of the Byzantine period.

response:
## Historical Significance of Albania in Relation to Egnatia Street

Egnatia Street, a central avenue in Thessaloniki, Greece, has deep historical roots that trace back to the Roman period. Originally constructed in the 2nd century BC, it served as a vital part of the Roman road network connecting Dyrrhachium (modern-day Durrës, Albania) to Constantinople (Istanbul, Turkey). This connection highlights the importance of Egnatia Street not only as a thoroughfare for trade and travel but also as a significant link between the regions of Greece and Albania during ancient times.

### Trade and Cultural Exchange

The establishment of Egnatia Street facilitated the movement of goods, people, and ideas between the East and West. As a major route, it enabled trade between Thessaloniki and the Albanian coast, contributing to the economic and cultural exchanges that shaped the region. The street's role in connecting these two areas underscores its significance in fostering relationships and interactions among diverse cultures throughout history [Data: Sources (60, 34); Reports (252)].

### Architectural and Urban Development

Egnatia Street has also played a crucial role in the urban development of Thessaloniki. The street is lined with various historical landmarks and buildings that reflect the architectural styles of different periods, including Roman, Byzantine, and Ottoman influences. This architectural diversity is a testament to the city's rich history and its connections to neighboring regions, including Albania. The street's evolution over the centuries has been influenced by its strategic importance as a trade route, which has shaped the urban landscape of Thessaloniki [Data: Entities (433, 1744); Relationships (316, 713)].

### Conclusion

In summary, Egnatia Street serves as a historical artery that connects Thessaloniki to Albania, highlighting the significance of trade, cultural exchange, and urban development in the region. Its origins as a Roman road and its continued relevance in the historical narrative of Thessaloniki illustrate the enduring impact of this route on the city's identity and its relationships with neighboring areas. The street remains a vital part of Thessaloniki's heritage, reflecting the intertwined histories of Greece and Albania [Data: Sources (60, 34); Reports (252)].
reference: Egnatia Street is historically significant as it was part of the road constructed by the Romans in the 2nd century BC, connecting Dyrrhachium (modern-day Durrës in Albania) with Constantinople.

reference_contexts: ['34 1 EGNATIA STREET This central avenue has been there practically since Thessaloniki’s founding, as it is a section of the road constructed by the Romans in the 2nd c. BC, and connected Dyrrhachium (Durrës, in modern day Albania) with Constantinople. It starts at Dimokratia square (see p. 58) and ends at the TIF grounds (see p. 31) and the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, splitting in two the town’s historic centre. It is a busy shopping area with numerous remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style dating to the early 20th c. (mostly old hotels) that are absolutely worth observing, as well as some of the city’s most important monuments. MUST SEE: 1.1 Kolomvou Square. The crossroads where Egnatia Street meets Antigonidon Street is indeed a bustling one! It was named after G. Colombo, an Italian who opened a hotel there in the early 20th century. This is the location of Kolomvou Archway (31, Egnatia St.) which has become a leisure hub with cafés, bars and restaurants inside. 1.2 Hamza Bey Mosque. It was built in 1467 by the daughter of Hamza Bey, the military commander of Sultan Murad II. It is the only mosque in Greece with a peristyle (a colonnaded yard). For many decades it housed a cinema named Alkazar. Currently there are renovation works under way. Once they are finished, it will house an exhibition of finds unearthed during the metro excavations. Right behind it you will see the City Manor which housed the Town Hall until recently. It is known at Karavan Serai as there used to be an ottoman inn here. (early 16th c.). 4th walk:']
response:
### Overview of TIF Grounds

The TIF Grounds, or Thessaloniki International Fair Grounds, is a significant cultural and commercial venue located in Thessaloniki, Greece. Established in 1926, it has become a central hub for various events, including the renowned Thessaloniki International Fair (TIF), which showcases industries and innovations from Greece and beyond. The fair is a major event in the Balkans, attracting millions of visitors each year and contributing significantly to the local economy and cultural landscape [Data: Entities (726, 703); Relationships (2329, 468)].

### Historical Significance

The TIF Grounds serve as the endpoint of Egnatia Street, a historically significant avenue that connects various important landmarks in Thessaloniki. Egnatia Street itself has roots dating back to Roman and Byzantine times, originally functioning as a major thoroughfare. The relationship between Egnatia Street and the TIF Grounds underscores the importance of this area as a hub for economic and cultural exchange [Data: Entities (433, 742); Relationships (513)].

### Surrounding Attractions

1. **Egnatia Street**: This central avenue is lined with numerous shops, cafés, and historical buildings, making it a vibrant area for both locals and tourists. The street is known for its eclectic and art deco architecture, particularly from the early 20th century [Data: Sources (34)].

2. **Dimokratia Square**: Located at the starting point of Egnatia Street, this square serves as a gathering place and is surrounded by various historical sites. It plays a crucial role in the urban landscape of Thessaloniki, often hosting community events and public gatherings [Data: Reports (308)].

3. **Presentation of the Lord Church**: Situated along Egnatia Street, this church is known for its historical significance and artistic depictions. It enhances the cultural value of the area and attracts visitors interested in its architectural features [Data: Reports (308)].

4. **Cultural Venues**: The TIF Grounds are not only a site for trade fairs but also host various cultural events throughout the year, including exhibitions and performances. This makes the area a dynamic center for cultural engagement in Thessaloniki [Data: Sources (60)].

5. **Nearby Parks and Recreational Areas**: The vicinity of TIF Grounds includes Tsirogiannis Park, a small public park surrounded by cafés and bars, providing a recreational space for both locals and visitors [Data: Entities (645)].

### Conclusion

The TIF Grounds and its surrounding areas in Thessaloniki represent a blend of historical significance, cultural vibrancy, and commercial activity. With its strategic location at the end of Egnatia Street and proximity to various landmarks, it serves as a focal point for both economic and cultural exchanges in the city. Visitors to Thessaloniki can enjoy a rich tapestry of experiences, from exploring historical sites to participating in vibrant cultural events. This area truly encapsulates the essence of Thessaloniki's dynamic character [Data: Entities (0, 3); Relationships (468, 2332)].
reference: The TIF grounds are located at the end of Egnatia Street, which is a central avenue in Thessaloniki that has been there since the city's founding. This area is part of a busy shopping district filled with remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style from the early 20th century. Nearby, you can find Kolomvou Square, a bustling crossroads with cafés, bars, and restaurants, as well as the Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467, which is notable for its peristyle. The mosque is currently undergoing renovations and will soon house an exhibition of finds from metro excavations.

of Macedonia; Byzantine

and also Jewish and western

creating unique culinary 
combinations. Downtown (see

suburbs and city outskirts (see 
p. 63 - 69), the traditional 
tavernas, ouzo restaurants and 
luxury restaurants highlight the 
local traditional gastronomy 
often creatively mixing it with 
gourmet tastes. 
Thessaloniki’s gastronomy 
can boast some pretty 
impressive delicacies 
[mezedes] such as gyro [slices 
of meat roasted on a spit] and 
souvlaki, patsa, a variety of 
soup, pies, Anatolian dishes 
(tzigerosarmades, giaprakia, 
gardoumpes, kebab etc), 
lake and sea fish, seafood 
delicacies (mussel pilaf, 
saganaki with shrimps, stuffed 
calamari etc). Confectionery 
is also an important part 
of local gastronomy and it 
features the renowned syrupy 
cakes and pastry originating 
from Istanbul (ekmek kadayifi, 
kazandibi, tulumba etc) the 
well-known bougatsa [filled 
either with cheese or with 
cream], galaktompoureko 
[a type of pastry filled with 
custard], and last but not least 
trigona Panoramatos [a cone-
shaped syrupy cream-filled puff 
pastry] (see p. 65). Koulouri 
Thessalonikis is also worthy 
of mention. It is a sesame-
covered piece of bread and 
an everyday snack for locals, 
which you can find in the 
morning hours sold by street 
vendors or at the', 'ations

throughout the entire day.

reference_contexts: ['34 1 EGNATIA STREET This central avenue has been there practically since Thessaloniki’s founding, as it is a section of the road constructed by the Romans in the 2nd c. BC, and connected Dyrrhachium (Durrës, in modern day Albania) with Constantinople. It starts at Dimokratia square (see p. 58) and ends at the TIF grounds (see p. 31) and the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, splitting in two the town’s historic centre. It is a busy shopping area with numerous remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style dating to the early 20th c. (mostly old hotels) that are absolutely worth observing, as well as some of the city’s most important monuments. MUST SEE: 1.1 Kolomvou Square. The crossroads where Egnatia Street meets Antigonidon Street is indeed a bustling one! It was named after G. Colombo, an Italian who opened a hotel there in the early 20th century. This is the location of Kolomvou Archway (31, Egnatia St.) which has become a leisure hub with cafés, bars and restaurants inside. 1.2 Hamza Bey Mosque. It was built in 1467 by the daughter of Hamza Bey, the military commander of Sultan Murad II. It is the only mosque in Greece with a peristyle (a colonnaded yard). For many decades it housed a cinema named Alkazar. Currently there are renovation works under way. Once they are finished, it will house an exhibition of finds unearthed during the metro excavations. Right behind it you will see the City Manor which housed the Town Hall until recently. It is known at Karavan Serai as there used to be an ottoman inn here. (early 16th c.). 4th walk:']
response:
## Interesting Places to Visit in Thessaloniki

Thessaloniki, Greece's second-largest city, is rich in history and culture, offering a variety of fascinating sites for visitors. Here are some of the most interesting places to explore:

### 1. The White Tower

The White Tower is perhaps the most iconic landmark of Thessaloniki. Built in the late 15th century, it originally served as a fortification and later as a prison. Today, it stands as a symbol of the city and houses a museum that showcases its history. The tower's architectural beauty and historical significance make it a must-visit for anyone exploring Thessaloniki [Data: Entities (628); Relationships (4, 205)].

### 2. Historic Centre of Thessaloniki

The Historic Centre is a culturally significant area that reflects the city's rich architectural heritage. It features a blend of modern and traditional Macedonian architecture, with key landmarks such as the Agios Minas Church and the Jewish Museum. This area is not only a focal point for cultural activities but also a vibrant hub for tourism, showcasing the city's extensive history through its ancient buildings and archaeological sites [Data: Reports (304); Entities (3)].

### 3. Jewish Museum of Thessaloniki

Located in the heart of the city, the Jewish Museum of Thessaloniki is dedicated to preserving the rich history and heritage of the Jewish community in the region. Established in 1997, the museum features permanent exhibits that highlight various aspects of Jewish life, including the Jewish Necropolis and a comprehensive history exhibition. This museum plays a vital role in promoting the Sephardic legacy and educating visitors about the Jewish community's contributions to Thessaloniki's cultural landscape [Data: Entities (549); Relationships (291)].

### 4. Archaeological Museum of Thessaloniki

The Archaeological Museum of Thessaloniki is renowned for its extensive collection of artifacts that date back to prehistoric times through late antiquity. It showcases significant finds from the region of Macedonia, providing visitors with a comprehensive insight into the area's rich cultural heritage. The museum is a key destination for those interested in the ancient history of Thessaloniki and its surroundings [Data: Entities (1425); Relationships (404)].

### 5. Ano Poli (Upper Town)

Ano Poli, or the Upper Town, is a historic district known for its traditional architecture and stunning views of the city. This area is characterized by its narrow streets, Byzantine churches, and remnants of the city's ancient walls. Ano Poli offers a glimpse into Thessaloniki's past and is a popular spot for both locals and tourists to enjoy traditional tavernas and local delicacies [Data: Entities (4); Relationships (712)].

## Conclusion

Thessaloniki is a city that beautifully intertwines its rich history with modern life. From the iconic White Tower to the culturally significant Historic Centre and the poignant Jewish Museum, each site tells a story that contributes to the city's vibrant identity. Whether you're interested in architecture, history, or local culture, Thessaloniki has something to offer every traveler.
reference: In Thessaloniki, one must visit Egnatia Street, a central avenue that has existed since the city's founding, originally constructed by the Romans in the 2nd century BC. It connects Dyrrhachium with Constantinople and is a busy shopping area featuring remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style from the early 20th century. Another highlight is Kolomvou Square, a bustling crossroads named after G. Colombo, where you can find the Kolomvou Archway, a leisure hub with cafés and restaurants. Additionally, the Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467, is notable for being the only mosque in Greece with a peristyle and is currently undergoing renovations to house an exhibition of archaeological finds. Nearby is the City Manor, known as Karavan Serai, which served as the Town Hall until recently.

reference_contexts: ['34 1 EGNATIA STREET This central avenue has been there practically since Thessaloniki’s founding, as it is a section of the road constructed by the Romans in the 2nd c. BC, and connected Dyrrhachium (Durrës, in modern day Albania) with Constantinople. It starts at Dimokratia square (see p. 58) and ends at the TIF grounds (see p. 31) and the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, splitting in two the town’s historic centre. It is a busy shopping area with numerous remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style dating to the early 20th c. (mostly old hotels) that are absolutely worth observing, as well as some of the city’s most important monuments. MUST SEE: 1.1 Kolomvou Square. The crossroads where Egnatia Street meets Antigonidon Street is indeed a bustling one! It was named after G. Colombo, an Italian who opened a hotel there in the early 20th century. This is the location of Kolomvou Archway (31, Egnatia St.) which has become a leisure hub with cafés, bars and restaurants inside. 1.2 Hamza Bey Mosque. It was built in 1467 by the daughter of Hamza Bey, the military commander of Sultan Murad II. It is the only mosque in Greece with a peristyle (a colonnaded yard). For many decades it housed a cinema named Alkazar. Currently there are renovation works under way. Once they are finished, it will house an exhibition of finds unearthed during the metro excavations. Right behind it you will see the City Manor which housed the Town Hall until recently. It is known at Karavan Serai as there used to be an ottoman inn here. (early 16th c.). 4th walk:']
response:
## Historical Significance of Constantinople in Relation to Egnatia Street

Constantinople, known today as Istanbul, was the capital of the Byzantine Empire and played a crucial role in the history of the region. Its strategic location made it a center of trade, culture, and politics, influencing many surrounding areas, including Thessaloniki. Egnatia Street, a major thoroughfare in Thessaloniki, has historical roots that trace back to the Roman period, originally serving as part of the Via Egnatia, which connected Dyrrhachium (modern-day Durrës, Albania) to Constantinople. This connection facilitated not only trade but also cultural exchanges between the two cities, making Egnatia Street a vital artery for movement and commerce in the ancient world [Data: Sources (60, 34); Entities (433, 1261)].

### Egnatia Street's Role in Urban Connectivity

Egnatia Street has been a significant route throughout history, linking various important sites within Thessaloniki and serving as a commercial hub. Its historical importance is underscored by its function as a major thoroughfare that enhanced urban connectivity, allowing for the flow of goods and people between Thessaloniki and Constantinople. This connection was particularly vital during the Byzantine period when Thessaloniki was a co-reigning city alongside Constantinople, reflecting its importance in the empire [Data: Sources (60, 34); Relationships (316, 1305)].

### Cultural and Economic Impact

The relationship between Constantinople and Egnatia Street also had profound cultural and economic implications. As a key route, Egnatia Street facilitated the movement of not only merchants but also ideas, art, and religious practices between the two cities. This exchange contributed to the rich cultural tapestry of Thessaloniki, which was influenced by the Byzantine heritage that Constantinople epitomized. The street itself is lined with historical landmarks and buildings that reflect this shared heritage, making it a focal point for both locals and visitors interested in the city's past [Data: Sources (60, 34); Entities (433, 1261)].

In summary, the historical significance of Constantinople in relation to Egnatia Street lies in their interconnectedness through trade, culture, and urban development. Egnatia Street served as a vital link that not only facilitated commerce but also enriched the cultural landscape of Thessaloniki, reflecting the broader historical narrative of the Byzantine Empire.
reference: Egnatia Street is a section of the road constructed by the Romans in the 2nd century BC, which connected Dyrrhachium (modern-day Durrës, Albania) with Constantinople, highlighting its historical significance as a vital route in ancient times.

(to create a civic centre);  
in 1966, however, excavations 
on the spot revealed the 
Ancient Roman Forum and  
the process was halted. In  
the centre of the square stands 
the imposing bust of Eleftherios 
Venizelos (1977, G. Pappas), 
who remained a prime minister 
of Greece for more than 12 
years during the period 1910 – 
1932. There are small copper 
workshops in the adjacent 
Chalkeon and Kleisouras 
Streets, and their business has 
been an ongoing tradition since 
the byzantine period.
1.4  Panagia [Virgin Mary] 
Chalkeon.
(see p. 9)
1.5  Bey Hamami.
It lies on the SE side of  
Plateia Dikastirion. This impressive 
edifice was built in 1444 and  
it is the country’s largest 
ottoman bath house, a multi-
domed construction with 
separate rooms for males and 
females, structured along two 
parallel ways. It is divided in 
three sections (cold, tepid 
and hot areas) and there is 
also a vaulted tank for heating 
water. It is widely known as the 
Paradise Baths and it went by 
that name until 1968. Right next 
to it there is a roman platform 
that is indicative of the ground 
level 2000 years ago.
1.6  Roman (Ancient) Forum
During the roman period, 
this 2-hectare area used to be 
the social and religious centre 
of the city. Construction was 
completed in two phases  
(in the mid-2nd and mid-  
3rd centuries AD) and it was 
gradually abandoned after the 
7th century. The NW section 
of', '

HISTORIC CENTRE (3)
that the place had been used 
by Christians as well, during 
the late Roman period. South 
of the passageway there 
were shops dating from the 
1st until the 13th century; the 
underground Museum of the 
Roman Forum (see p. 71) was 
built there as an extension. 
A 2nd - 4th c. AD Odeon [C] 
was found behind the well-
preserved eastern stoa. It  
has been restored and it is now 
used as a venue for cultural 
events. A mint and an archive 
office are right next to it. In the 
SE side, a round bath house 
[D] was unearthed which has 
been in use since the 1st c. BC. 
Parts of a colonnade, mosaic 
floors, marble stairs, a section 
of a stone-paved street, sewer 
pipes, silver coins, stone and 
marble sculptures were all 
found in this archaeological 
site. The forum is also where 
the “Enchanted Ones” (las 
Incantadas) were discovered, 
a two-storeyed colonnaded 
archway with Corinthian-order 
columns and pillars four of 
which have survived. They are 
decorated with figures in relief 
in their interior as well as their 
exterior side (“Stoa of the

reference_contexts: ['35 4th walk: HISTORIC CENTRE (3) 1.3 Plateia Dikastirion [Court house square]. A spacious green square situated towards the end of Aristotelous Street. The Hébrard plans placed construction of the Court House as well as of other state buildings on this location (to create a civic centre); in 1966, however, excavations on the spot revealed the Ancient Roman Forum and the process was halted. In the centre of the square stands the imposing bust of Eleftherios Venizelos (1977, G. Pappas), who remained a prime minister of Greece for more than 12 years during the period 1910 – 1932. There are small copper workshops in the adjacent Chalkeon and Kleisouras Streets, and their business has been an ongoing tradition since the byzantine period. 1.4 Panagia [Virgin Mary] Chalkeon. (see p. 9) 1.5 Bey Hamami. It lies on the SE side of Plateia Dikastirion. This impressive edifice was built in 1444 and it is the country’s largest ottoman bath house, a multi- domed construction with separate rooms for males and females, structured along two parallel ways. It is divided in three sections (cold, tepid and hot areas) and there is also a vaulted tank for heating water. It is widely known as the Paradise Baths and it went by that name until 1968. Right next to it there is a roman platform that is indicative of the ground level 2000 years ago. 1.6']
response:
## Overview of the Ancient Roman Forum

The Ancient Roman Forum, located in Central Macedonia, is a significant historical site that served as the social and religious center of the city during the Roman era. Its construction dates back to the mid-2nd to mid-3rd centuries AD, covering an area of approximately 2 hectares. The Forum is recognized for its archaeological importance, showcasing a variety of artifacts that reflect the cultural heritage of the region [Data: Entities (797); Reports (326)].

## Historical Significance

### Social and Religious Hub

The Roman Forum was not just a marketplace; it was a vital public space where social, political, and religious activities took place. It functioned as a central gathering point for citizens, facilitating various communal interactions and events. The Forum's role as a museum today highlights its ongoing relevance in cultural discussions and tourism, preserving the history of the area [Data: Reports (326)].

### Architectural Features

Excavations at the Forum have revealed a wealth of architectural features, including parts of a colonnade, mosaic floors, and marble stairs. These findings illustrate the advanced engineering and artistic capabilities of the time. Notably, the Forum also housed the "Enchanted Ones" (Las Incantadas), a two-storeyed colonnaded archway that has become a symbol of the site's historical richness [Data: Sources (70), Reports (326)].

### Adjacent Historical Entities

The Forum is closely linked to several adjacent historical entities, such as Panagia Chalkeon, a church dedicated to the Virgin Mary, and Chalkeon and Kleisouras Streets, known for their ongoing tradition of copper workshops since the Byzantine period. This proximity indicates a vibrant community that thrived around the Forum, contributing to its historical narrative [Data: Reports (326); Entities (798, 799)].

## Archaeological Discoveries

The excavations at Plateia Dikastirion have unearthed numerous artifacts and structures that provide insights into the daily life and practices of the ancient inhabitants. Among the significant findings are remnants of luxury houses associated with historical figures like Epigenis and Evvoulos, known for their exquisite mosaics. These discoveries underscore the area's historical wealth and artistic achievements during the Roman period [Data: Entities (1668, 1669); Reports (326)].

### Proposed Civic Centre

Interestingly, there are plans for a proposed Civic Centre to be built on the location of the Ancient Roman Forum. This development raises questions about the preservation of the Forum's historical integrity and its role in the community. The Civic Centre could serve as a modern hub for social and cultural activities, bridging the past with the present [Data: Relationships (652); Reports (326)].

## Conclusion

The Ancient Roman Forum is a cornerstone of the historical landscape in Central Macedonia, reflecting the social, religious, and architectural dynamics of its time. The ongoing excavations and discoveries at Plateia Dikastirion continue to enrich our understanding of this significant site, making it a vital destination for both historians and tourists alike. The interplay between the ancient and modern, particularly with the proposed Civic Centre, highlights the importance of preserving such historical sites while accommodating contemporary needs [Data: Reports (326)].
reference: The Ancient Roman Forum was revealed during excavations at Plateia Dikastirion in 1966, which halted the construction of the Court House and other state buildings intended to create a civic center. This discovery highlights the historical significance of the site, as it reflects the urban planning and architectural practices of ancient Rome. The forum served as a central public space in Roman cities, where various activities, including political, social, and commercial events, took place.

of the 3rd Army Corps and it 
was named after Papafeio 
Orphanage that once dominated  
the area.
MUST SEE:
O Melitefs Papafeio 
Orphanage (33, Papafi and 
Katsimidou Sts.). Construction 
was completed in 1903  
(to plans by Xen. Paionidis), 
after a bequest made by  
a Thessalonian called I. Papafis 
(1792 – 1866) who lived 
and died in Malta (former 
name: Meliti). This is a typical 
classical style building with 
three floors and a propulaeum 
in the main entrance. It served 
as a male boarding school and 
it was also used as military 
barracks and hospital. It is 
surrounded by impressive 
gardens with a small church 
built there of late.
YFANET textile factory. 
Located at a short distance 
from Papafeio Orphanage, 
the factory covered an area of 
4,000 m2 and used to be one 
of the largest textile units in 
Macedonia from 1926 until 
1964 when it was closed down 
and deserted. Plans are made 
to transfer here the State', 'as a boarding school; today 
it houses a Traffic Police 
Department. Opposite to it, 
there is a small garden with  
a small Roman Catholic chapel 
dedicated to the Sacred Heart 
of Jesus.
3.5  Mehmet Kapanci Villa 
(108, Vas. Olgas Ave.).
The mansion was built in 1893 
to plans by the Italian architect 
P. Arrigoni, within a 0.4 hectare 
garden, for Mehmet Kapanci,  
a Thessalonian Jewish merchant 
and banker. Following the central 
European architectural trend of 
the time, the main building is  
a three storey construction with 
elaborate interior decoration 
and has access to a tower. 
Prince Nicholas, the city’s first 
Greek military commander, was 
accommodated here in 1912; 
in 1916-1917 E. Venizelos 
stayed in the villa as head of 
the temporary revolutionary 
Government of National Defence. 
In 1928 the building was bought 
by the National Bank of Greece 
and during the years 1938 – 
1961 it housed some of the city’s 
highschools. Since 1989, this  
is the location of the Thessaloniki  
Cultural Centre of the National 
Bank of Greece Cultural 
Foundation (MIET, see p. 77). 
Next to it there is a red brick 
castle, known as Chateau mon 
bonheur, dating to 1890.
3.6  Ahmet Kapanci Villa 
(105, Vas. Olgas Ave.).
It was built in 1905 by P. 
Arrigoni, as a country (seaside) 
residence for Ahmet Kapanci,  
a Jewish merchant and Mayor 
of the City. The architectural 
style is a mixed one as the 
eclectic features combine', 'It was designed by Xenophon 
Paionidis and built in 1924; 
today it houses shops and 
offices. On the opposite side 
of I. Dragoumi Street, there 
is a 1925 listed building with 
curved balconies.
6.2  Agios [Saint] Minas 
Church.
Situated at the market 
centre, the church was built 
on the location of an early 
Christian basilica, of which 
remains only the semi-circular 
conch of the sanctuary and 
the pulpit. It was burned twice 
since 1806 and in 1852 it 
was finally shaped as a three-
13

22
2nd walk: 
HISTORIC CENTRE (1)
TRADITIONAL COMMERCIAL CENTRE
aisled post-byzantine basilica. 
The interior decoration is of 
particular interest as it shows 
influences from baroque, 
rococo and neoclassical styles.
6.3  The Jewish Museum 
of Thessaloniki.
It is housed in a 1904 historic 
building (V. Poselli), which 
survived the 1917 fire and is 
owned by Jews. There used to 
be a shopping arcade there, 
once, and it has –at times- 
housed a bank and the offices 
of a jewish newspaper (for 
museum exhibits, see p. 73).
6.4  Venizelou street. 
A very busy street linking 
Eleftherias sq. with the 
Residency since 1867 (see p. 39). 
It is a shopping street lined 
with many interesting buildings 
of eclectic and art deco style, 
mostly up to Egnatia street 
(see p. 34). On the north side 
of the junction of Venizelou 
and Tsimiski streets, lies the 
', ' 
boutiques and also tavernas, 
ouzo restaurants and coffee 
shops.
MUST SEE:
7.1  Modiano Market.
It was built in 1922 by 
engineer E. Modiano, and it is 
known as Modiano Market. It 
is a glass-roofed rectangular 
edifice containing 140 food 
shops inside its three arcades. 
You will find choice traditional 
products here and a number of 
particularly popular restaurants 
inside the complex as well as 
along the perimeter.
7.2  Vlali-Kapani & 
Athonos-Vatikioti Markets.
Designed by Ernest Hébrard, 
they intersect Aristotelous 
street vertically and they are 
connected to it via special 
passageways. These are 
complexes of two-storeyed 
malls with archways on the 
ground floor. Vlali-Kapani 
market is located on the west 
side of Aristotelous street, 
where Un Kapani (flour market) 
used to be during the time 
of the Turkish Occupation. 
This spot is a food and 
spices market; in the small

Lagkadas (see p. 93). Buses run 
from 5 am until midnight, yet 
there are certain lines running 
after midnight connecting major 
junctions. You can purchase a 
bus pass (one-month, three-

use a ticket: the one-way basic

1.7  Bit-Pazar.
An edifice with lots of 
atmosphere, Bit Pazar (meaning 
Small Market place) is a spot 
where the town’s antique shops 
are to be found. Its ground level 
was constructed in 1930 and 
higher floors were added in the 
1960s. Facing the inner square 
and lining the surrounding 
streets namely Tositsa (where 
the main entrance is), Venizelou 
and Olympou, there are many 
second-hand shops, antique 
dealers’ and furniture shops. 
In recent years the variety of 
restaurants, ouzo tavernas 
and café-bars has made it a 
hot spot particularly among 
students. Within a short 
distance (at 35, Syngrou 
St.) you will see the Jewish 
Monastirioton Synagogue  
the only one to have survived

reference_contexts: ['35 4th walk: HISTORIC CENTRE (3) 1.3 Plateia Dikastirion [Court house square]. A spacious green square situated towards the end of Aristotelous Street. The Hébrard plans placed construction of the Court House as well as of other state buildings on this location (to create a civic centre); in 1966, however, excavations on the spot revealed the Ancient Roman Forum and the process was halted. In the centre of the square stands the imposing bust of Eleftherios Venizelos (1977, G. Pappas), who remained a prime minister of Greece for more than 12 years during the period 1910 – 1932. There are small copper workshops in the adjacent Chalkeon and Kleisouras Streets, and their business has been an ongoing tradition since the byzantine period. 1.4 Panagia [Virgin Mary] Chalkeon. (see p. 9) 1.5 Bey Hamami. It lies on the SE side of Plateia Dikastirion. This impressive edifice was built in 1444 and it is the country’s largest ottoman bath house, a multi- domed construction with separate rooms for males and females, structured along two parallel ways. It is divided in three sections (cold, tepid and hot areas) and there is also a vaulted tank for heating water. It is widely known as the Paradise Baths and it went by that name until 1968. Right next to it there is a roman platform that is indicative of the ground level 2000 years ago. 1.6']
response:
## Who is Eleftherios Venizelos?

Eleftherios Venizelos was a prominent Greek politician who served as Prime Minister of Greece for over 12 years between 1910 and 1932. He is widely regarded as one of the most significant figures in modern Greek history due to his influential role in shaping the country's political landscape during a tumultuous period. Venizelos was known for his efforts to modernize Greece and navigate through critical events, including World War I and the subsequent political instability that followed.

## Importance of Eleftherios Venizelos

### Political Legacy

Venizelos's political legacy is marked by his leadership during the establishment of the National Defence Government in Thessaloniki in 1916. This government was formed in response to significant political instability and aimed to unify various factions within Greece during a time of internal conflict and external pressures. His ability to rally support and create a cohesive political front was crucial in stabilizing the nation during these challenging times [Data: Reports (98); Entities (55, 48)].

### Modernization Efforts

Throughout his tenure, Venizelos implemented policies that aimed to modernize Greece, focusing on economic development, social reforms, and strengthening the military. His vision for a modern Greece laid the groundwork for future advancements in the country, making him a key figure in its historical narrative [Data: Reports (333); Entities (794)].

### Cultural Significance

Venizelos's contributions extend beyond politics; he is also commemorated through various cultural artifacts, such as the bust created by artist G. Pappas, which stands in Eleftherias Square in Thessaloniki. This bust serves as a symbol of respect and admiration for his contributions to the nation, reinforcing his legacy in the public consciousness [Data: Reports (333); Relationships (645)].

In summary, Eleftherios Venizelos is a pivotal figure in Greek history, known for his political leadership, modernization efforts, and cultural significance. His impact on Greece continues to be felt today, making him a subject of study and admiration in both historical and contemporary contexts.
reference: Eleftherios Venizelos was a prime minister of Greece for more than 12 years during the period 1910 – 1932. His bust stands in the centre of Plateia Dikastirion, which is a spacious green square in the historic centre.

reference_contexts: ['35 4th walk: HISTORIC CENTRE (3) 1.3 Plateia Dikastirion [Court house square]. A spacious green square situated towards the end of Aristotelous Street. The Hébrard plans placed construction of the Court House as well as of other state buildings on this location (to create a civic centre); in 1966, however, excavations on the spot revealed the Ancient Roman Forum and the process was halted. In the centre of the square stands the imposing bust of Eleftherios Venizelos (1977, G. Pappas), who remained a prime minister of Greece for more than 12 years during the period 1910 – 1932. There are small copper workshops in the adjacent Chalkeon and Kleisouras Streets, and their business has been an ongoing tradition since the byzantine period. 1.4 Panagia [Virgin Mary] Chalkeon. (see p. 9) 1.5 Bey Hamami. It lies on the SE side of Plateia Dikastirion. This impressive edifice was built in 1444 and it is the country’s largest ottoman bath house, a multi- domed construction with separate rooms for males and females, structured along two parallel ways. It is divided in three sections (cold, tepid and hot areas) and there is also a vaulted tank for heating water. It is widely known as the Paradise Baths and it went by that name until 1968. Right next to it there is a roman platform that is indicative of the ground level 2000 years ago. 1.6']
response:
### Overview of Paradise Baths

Paradise Baths, known as **Bey Hamami**, is a historical bathhouse located in Thessaloniki, Greece. Built in **1444**, it is recognized as the largest Ottoman bathhouse in the country. The structure is notable for its multi-domed architecture and features separate areas for males and females, reflecting the traditional practices of the time. The bathhouse is divided into three sections: cold, tepid, and hot areas, along with a vaulted tank for heating water, which was essential for the bathing experience [Data: Entities (796); Sources (1.5)].

### Historical Significance

The bathhouse is not only a significant architectural landmark but also a representation of the Ottoman influence on Greek culture and architecture. It is situated near the **City Walls**, which adds to its historical context, showcasing the rich heritage of Thessaloniki during the Ottoman period [Data: Relationships (2404); Sources (30)].

### Cultural Context

Bey Hamami, or Paradise Baths, serves as a reminder of the social and cultural practices of the Ottoman era, where bathhouses were central to community life. They were places not just for bathing but also for socializing and relaxation. The architectural design of Bey Hamami, with its intricate domes and spacious interiors, reflects the importance of such establishments in the daily lives of the people during that time [Data: Sources (1.5)].

In summary, Paradise Baths is a significant historical site that embodies the architectural and cultural legacy of the Ottoman period in Thessaloniki, making it a noteworthy destination for visitors interested in the city's rich history.
reference: Paradise Baths, also known as Bey Hamami, is the country’s largest Ottoman bath house, built in 1444. It features a multi-domed construction with separate rooms for males and females, divided into cold, tepid, and hot areas, and includes a vaulted tank for heating water.

reference_contexts: ['35 4th walk: HISTORIC CENTRE (3) 1.3 Plateia Dikastirion [Court house square]. A spacious green square situated towards the end of Aristotelous Street. The Hébrard plans placed construction of the Court House as well as of other state buildings on this location (to create a civic centre); in 1966, however, excavations on the spot revealed the Ancient Roman Forum and the process was halted. In the centre of the square stands the imposing bust of Eleftherios Venizelos (1977, G. Pappas), who remained a prime minister of Greece for more than 12 years during the period 1910 – 1932. There are small copper workshops in the adjacent Chalkeon and Kleisouras Streets, and their business has been an ongoing tradition since the byzantine period. 1.4 Panagia [Virgin Mary] Chalkeon. (see p. 9) 1.5 Bey Hamami. It lies on the SE side of Plateia Dikastirion. This impressive edifice was built in 1444 and it is the country’s largest ottoman bath house, a multi- domed construction with separate rooms for males and females, structured along two parallel ways. It is divided in three sections (cold, tepid and hot areas) and there is also a vaulted tank for heating water. It is widely known as the Paradise Baths and it went by that name until 1968. Right next to it there is a roman platform that is indicative of the ground level 2000 years ago. 1.6']
response:
### Overview of Kleisouras Street

Kleisouras Street is a notable street located adjacent to the Ancient Roman Forum in Thessaloniki, Greece. It is recognized for its ongoing tradition of copper workshops that date back to the Byzantine period. This historical significance contributes to the cultural landscape of the area, making it an important point of interest for both locals and visitors.

### Cultural and Historical Significance

The street's connection to the Ancient Roman Forum highlights its role in the historical narrative of Thessaloniki. The presence of copper workshops along Kleisouras Street reflects a long-standing artisanal tradition that has been maintained through generations. This aspect not only enriches the local economy but also preserves the cultural heritage of the city, showcasing the craftsmanship that has been a part of Thessaloniki's identity since the Byzantine era [Data: Entities (799); Sources (70)].

### Connection to the Historic Center

Kleisouras Street is part of the Historic Centre of Thessaloniki, an area known for its rich historical heritage and architectural diversity. The street's proximity to significant landmarks, such as the Ancient Roman Forum, enhances its importance within the urban landscape. Visitors exploring the Historic Centre can appreciate the blend of modern and traditional elements that characterize the area, with Kleisouras Street serving as a vital link to the city's past [Data: Entities (3); Sources (70)].

### Conclusion

In summary, Kleisouras Street is not just a thoroughfare but a vital part of Thessaloniki's historical and cultural fabric. Its ongoing tradition of craftsmanship and its connection to significant historical sites make it a noteworthy destination for those interested in the city's rich heritage. The street exemplifies the blend of history and modernity that defines the Historic Centre of Thessaloniki, making it an essential stop for any visitor.
reference: Kleisouras Streets is located adjacent to the Court House square, known as Plateia Dikastirion, in the historic center. This area features small copper workshops that have been part of the local tradition since the Byzantine period, highlighting the street's historical significance and ongoing craftsmanship.

Thessaloniki’s central square 
is one of the largest and most 
impressive in Greece, and  
a bustling place twenty four 
hours a day. It is one of the 
few sections of the Hébrard 
Committee urban plan, which 
came to be realised after the 
1917 fire, although it became 
fully shaped in as late as the 
early 1960s. It is a square 
on the seafront, with a 100 
m. opening, that affords an 
amazing view of the Thermaic 
Gulf and the Olympus massif. 
The monumental style of 
architecture is shown in the 
buildings’ facades, colonnades, 
arcades and porticos, which 
combine elements from the 
city’s Byzantine tradition 
with European interwar 
period motifs. The square is 
landmarked by two identical 
concave buildings: Electra

response:
## The Roman Forum in Thessaloniki: A Historical Overview

The Roman Forum in Thessaloniki served as a vital social and religious center during ancient times. Constructed between the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD, this expansive area of approximately 2 hectares was the heart of public life in the city. It functioned as a gathering place for citizens, where various social, political, and religious activities took place, reflecting the cultural dynamics of the Roman era [Data: Reports (326); Entities (797)].

### Social and Religious Hub

The Forum was not only a marketplace but also a venue for public events and ceremonies. It was a place where citizens could engage in discussions, participate in religious rituals, and witness public announcements. The architectural layout included various structures that facilitated these activities, such as temples, basilicas, and public meeting spaces, which were integral to the community's social fabric [Data: Reports (326); Sources (70)].

### Economic Activities

Adjacent to the Roman Forum were streets like Chalkeon and Kleisouras, known for their copper workshops that have been in operation since the Byzantine period. This indicates that the Forum was also a center for trade and craftsmanship, contributing to the local economy. The ongoing tradition of these workshops highlights the Forum's role in supporting economic activities and trade practices that were essential for the community's livelihood [Data: Reports (326); Entities (798, 799); Relationships (650, 651)].

### Cultural Significance

The Roman Forum is recognized for its archaeological significance, showcasing a variety of artifacts that provide insights into the daily life and cultural practices of the time. It served as a museum of sorts, preserving the history and heritage of Thessaloniki. The presence of historical figures associated with luxury houses in the Forum, such as Epigenis and Evvoulos, further emphasizes its cultural importance, as these figures were known for their artistic contributions during the Roman period [Data: Reports (326); Entities (1668, 1669); Relationships (1857, 1858)].

### Conclusion

In summary, the Roman Forum in Thessaloniki was a multifaceted space that played a crucial role in the social, religious, and economic life of the city during ancient times. Its significance as a historical and cultural landmark continues to attract interest from historians and tourists alike, making it a vital part of Thessaloniki's rich heritage [Data: Reports (326); Entities (797)].
reference: During the Roman period, the Roman Forum was the social and religious centre of the city. It was constructed in two phases, completed in the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD, and was gradually abandoned after the 7th century.

response:
## Historical Significance of Macedonia in Relation to the Roman Forum

Macedonia, a historical region in Northern Greece, is renowned for its rich archaeological heritage and cultural significance, particularly during the Roman Empire. The Roman Forum, located in Central Macedonia, serves as a vital historical site that reflects the social and religious practices of the time. This ancient public space was constructed between the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD and functioned as the social and religious center of the city, showcasing the architectural and cultural advancements of the Roman period [Data: Reports (154), Entities (797); Relationships (647)].

### The Role of Thessaloniki

Thessaloniki, the capital of Macedonia, played a crucial role during the Roman Empire. It became the administrative center of the Roman province of Macedonia after the Romans took control in 168 BC. The city's development and culture were significantly influenced by its status within the empire, making it a focal point for governance and trade [Data: Reports (154), Entities (9, 25); Relationships (2, 18)]. The Roman Forum in Thessaloniki is a testament to this historical significance, as it was a hub for public life, commerce, and governance during the Roman era.

### Archaeological Importance

The archaeological findings at the Roman Forum provide valuable insights into the daily life and social structures of ancient Macedonia. Artifacts uncovered at the site, including remnants of shops, public baths, and religious structures, illustrate the vibrant community that thrived in this region during the Roman period. The forum's extensive excavations have revealed a wealth of information about the architectural styles and urban planning of the time, contributing to our understanding of Macedonia's historical narrative [Data: Reports (154), Entities (797); Relationships (681)].

### Cultural Heritage

Macedonia's cultural heritage is further enriched by its wine-making traditions, which date back to ancient times. The region is celebrated for its diverse grape varieties, which not only contribute to the local economy but also enhance its cultural identity. This aspect of Macedonian life was likely reflected in the social gatherings and events that took place in the Roman Forum, where wine would have played a significant role in communal activities [Data: Reports (154), Entities (9); Relationships (2025)].

In summary, Macedonia's historical significance in relation to the Roman Forum is multifaceted, encompassing its role as a center of governance, its archaeological importance, and its rich cultural heritage. The forum stands as a symbol of the region's vibrant past and its enduring influence on the cultural landscape of Greece. This connection to the Roman Empire continues to attract scholars and tourists alike, eager to explore the depths of Macedonia's historical legacy [Data: Reports (154), Entities (9, 25); Relationships (2, 18)].
reference: During the Roman period, Macedonia was home to a 2-hectare area that served as the social and religious center of the city, known as the Roman Forum. This site was constructed in two phases during the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD and was gradually abandoned after the 7th century.
