["<1-hop>

42 Thessaloniki’s Old Town is full of atmosphere. It covers the area in between the city walls (to the north and east) and Olympiados Street (to the south), and has had the luck to remain untouched by the 1917 great fire. It was virtually uninhabited until the mid-15th century, when it was conquered by the Ottomans who selected it for settlement on account of its fine climate, panoramic views and strategic position. The two and three-storey houses bear mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements (sachnisia) [Şahniş in turkish]; there are also residences with neoclassical and eclectic style motifs where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews. After 1922 many refugees settled in the area. Despite the construction of newer buildings and the opening up of new streets in recent decades, it has kept its original town planning, to a large extent, with narrow alleys and scant squares, as well as its original architectural features, particularly in the west and east part of the town. This particular atmosphere has lured intellects, artists and students who chose it for settlement in recent years. 1 \x07AGIA AIKATERINI [SAINT CATHERINE] CHURCH (see p. 12) NIKIS NIKIS GERMANOU SVOLOU IASONIDOU TSIMISKI VAS. response:
## Historical Significance of Thessaloniki's Old Town

Thessaloniki's Old Town, also known as Ano Poli, is a treasure trove of Macedonian heritage, showcasing a blend of architectural styles and historical narratives that date back centuries. This area has remained largely untouched since the great fire of 1917, preserving its unique character and offering a glimpse into the city's past. The Old Town is characterized by its traditional architecture, including notable structures such as the Profitis Ilias Church and the Panagia Lagoudiani Church, which exemplify Byzantine architectural styles. The remnants of the city's ancient walls and traces of habitation dating back to the 2nd century AD further emphasize its historical importance [Data: Entities (951); Relationships (4)].

The Old Town serves as a cultural hub, reflecting the vibrant local culture with numerous tavernas and café-bars where locals gather to enjoy traditional gastronomy. This neighborhood not only highlights the city's rich history but also connects visitors to the broader narrative of Thessaloniki's evolution through various historical epochs, including the Roman, Byzantine, and Ottoman periods [Data: Entities (4); Relationships (4)].

## Connection to the Roman Forum

The Roman Forum, located in the Historic Centre of Thessaloniki, is a significant archaeological site that serves as a vital link to the city's Roman past. Constructed between the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD, the Forum was the social and religious center of the city during the Roman era, encompassing an area of 2 hectares. It showcases a variety of artifacts and structures that highlight the cultural heritage of the region [Data: Reports (326); Entities (797)].

The proximity of the Old Town to the Roman Forum underscores the interconnectedness of these historical sites. The Forum's role as a central hub for social interactions and trade during the Roman period complements the Old Town's historical significance as a residential area that has preserved its architectural integrity. The streets leading to the Forum, such as Chalkeon and Kleisouras Streets, are known for their historical craftsmanship and ongoing traditions, further linking the two areas through their shared heritage [Data: Reports (326); Entities (798, 799)].

In summary, Thessaloniki's Old Town holds immense historical significance as a representation of Macedonian heritage, while its connection to the Roman Forum enriches the narrative of the city's past, illustrating the layers of cultural and historical influences that have shaped Thessaloniki over the centuries. This relationship between the Old Town and the Roman Forum not only enhances the understanding of the city's historical landscape but also attracts visitors interested in exploring its rich cultural tapestry.
reference: Thessaloniki's Old Town is significant for its Macedonian heritage as it showcases a blend of Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements, reflecting the city's diverse history. The area remained largely untouched by the 1917 great fire, preserving its original town planning and atmosphere, which has attracted artists and students. Additionally, the Roman Forum, which served as the social and religious center of the city during the Roman period, further emphasizes the historical depth of Thessaloniki. The Forum's construction in the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD and its gradual abandonment after the 7th century highlight the city's evolution through different eras, including its Macedonian roots.

MUSEUM AREA
The area is considered  
as one of the most privileged 
places downtown on account 
of its proximity to the beach;  
it is traditionally regarded as 
the residential area of the 
well-to-do. There are many 
well-known shops here, green 
spots, as well as some of the 
most important museums  
and cultural institutions.
1 	\x07
THE WHITE TOWER 
AREA
This central location is where 
major city roads meet (Nikis 
Ave, Megalou Alexandrou Ave., 
Pavlou Mela, Ethnikis Amynis, 
Germanou) and where the old 
part of the waterfront meets 
the new one. It affords a lovely 
view of the sea; there are 
green areas and many shops, 
cafés and bars.
MUST SEE:
1.1  The White Tower.
This is the city’s most 
famous landmark - 
monument. It was probably 
built in the late 15th c. on 
the location where the city’s 
eastern and seaside walls 
meet;", ' 
and you can see embossed 
depictions of Galerius’ military 
successes. It is connected  
to Rotunda via a wide 
pedestrian way. Right next to it  
lies Panagia Dexia church 
(1950s), built on the location 
of a postbyzantine church. 
In it there is a rare icon of 
Panagia (Virgin Mary) holding 
little Jesus on her right side.
1.13 Rotunda.
(see p. 10)
1.14 Agios [Saint] 
Panteleimon
(see p. 11)

[Fountain Square].

at the centre of this transport 
hub. It was built in 1866  
by Sultan Hamid as a gift  
to the city and it was at that 
time situated outside the 
east walls (Cassander’s Gate). 
During the Interwar Period a 
large part of it was removed 
to make Egnatia Street wider; 
it was restored to its original 
shape in 1977.
2 	\x07ARISTOTLE 
UNIVERSITY OF 
THESSALONIKI (AUTH).
This is the first University 
Campus in Greece (covering 
a 50 hectare area) to have 
been built following complete 
architectural plans. It was 
planned to be constructed 
on the location of the old 
Jewish cemetery (see p. 61), 
according to the Hébrard 
committee plan; construction 
finally began in 1938, yet the 
works were interrupted during 
the war and resumed in the 
1950s. Since then, several 
buildings were erected on 
these grounds by leading', ' a major Greek 
architect, and it was 
inaugurated in 1962. Inspired 
by the ancient Greek Revival 
Architectural style, it is 
considered as one of the most 
typical examples of modernist 
architectural design in Greece. 
An annex was added in 1980 
and in 2003 the museum  
was extensively remodelled  
to accommodate contemporary 
needs. There are rooms for 
periodic exhibitions, events 
and educational programmes, 
a café and a shop (see p.70  
for museum exhibits).  
1.7  Museum of Byzantine 
Culture.
It was built during the 
years 1989 – 1993, following 
the designs of architect K. 
Krokos. It combines elements 
of modernism and Greek 
architectural tradition and it 
is considered one of the best 
contemporary constructions 
meant for public use in Greece.  
In 2001 it was declared a 
listed historic monument and  
a work of art. Inside there is  
a small amphitheatre, a café-
restaurant and a wing for 
hosting periodic exhibitions 
(see p. 71 for museum 
exhibits). The adjacent 
building is the new Town Hall 
(inaugurated in 2009); at the 
back there is a park (formerly 
named Pedion Areos, a section 
of an old military camp), with 
a playground, a small lake and 
23.

building. 
Notice the 
neo-byzantine 
architectural 
elements.

10.2 OTE [Hellenic 
Telecommunications 
Organisation] Tower.
It was built in 1969 to plans 
by architect Al. Anastasiadis, 
as the Organisation’s 
exhibition pavilion, and for 
covering the city’s telecom 
needs. It dominates against 
the city’s horizon as it reaches 
a 70-metre height – including 
the antenna. Its storeys house 
radio stations and at a higher 
level there is a caffé with a 
rotating floor (completes a 
revolution in 70 min.), where 
the city and seafront views 
are amazing. At a very short 
distance lies the Radio 
Museum which is worth your 
visit (see the exhibits on p. 78).
10.3 Alexandreio 
Melathron.
Also known as Palais des 
Sports, this sports arena is 
located on the NE side of the 
Thessaloniki International Fair 
grounds. Constructed in 1966, 
it has played an active part 
in Thessaloniki’s history ever 
since, as major sporting, art 
as well as political events have 
taken place in it over the years.  
It is a round edifice with a 
seating for 4,800, and it used 
to be the largest indoor sports 
arena in Greece until 1985. 
Today, it is the home ground of 
Aris basketball team.
10', ' the city.
3.7  Ataturk Museum.
It is adjacent to the building 
of the Turkish consulate (75, Ap. 
Pavlou St.). This three-storey 
residence was built in the late 
19th c. and it was the house  
of Kemal Ataturk, born  
in Thessaloniki (1880? - 1938). 
In the yard, you will see  
a pomegranate tree his father  
had planted there. It is a building 
now painted in its original colour 
- pink – and houses

nowadays and

a small museum dedicated

Turkish state. To visit it you need

3.8  Teloglion Foundation 
of Art. 
Built on elevated ground in 
the north side of the Campus, 
it is a modern building complex 
covering a 3,200 m2 area and 
it was inaugurated in 1998. 
There are spatious exhibition 
areas, an amphitheatre,  
a library – reading room,  
as well as rooms for research 
and educational programmes, 
a shop and a café-restaurant  
(for the foundation’s collections 
see p. 76). Thessaloniki’s 
National Swimming Pool  
is located east of Teloglion. 
3.9  Kaftanzogleio Stadium.
It was built in 1960, following', ' 
Bank of Greece & the Bank 
of Greece (1928) and of the 
Ionian and Popular Bank (1929 
– today Alpha Bank); elements 
of late neoclassicism and 
interwar period eclecticism are 
evident on the outside of both 
buildings.
MUST SEE:
3.1  Kalapothaki Street.
It starts at Ladadika area, 
ends at Dimosthenous 
street and its biggest part is 
now pedestrianised. There 
are some very interesting 
neoclassical and Bauhaus-
style buildings with popular 
cafés, bar restaurants, and 
small hotels. Stein Building is 
at the corner of El. Venizelos 
and Kalapothaki Streets; it 
was built in 1908 in order to 
house a department store 
and it is one of the very few 
buildings that were spared 
destruction at the 1917 great 
fire. Notice the glass globe on 
the top of the building, a point 
of reference in Eleftherias Sq. 
In the neighbouring Komninon 
Street it is worth noticing the 
eclectic style on buildings 
such as Luxemburg Hotel as 
well as Tourist and Excelsior 
Hotels at the junction with 
Mitropoleos streets.
4 	PORT
The area is one of the biggest 
ports of the country and of the 
southeastern Mediterranean, 
with a significant trade and 
passenger traffic. This is where 
the first artificial harbour of 
the town was constructed by 
Constantine the Great during 
his short stay in Thessaloniki 
(322-323 AD); later on during 
the Turkish Occupation it 
was banked up with earth.

This is one of the very few 
main town areas that were 
spared destruction when 
the 1917 fire broke out. It 
was created in the 16th c. 
when the Turks banked the 
Byzantine artificial harbour 
up with earth, and ended in 
Fragkomachalas area (see p. 
22); Ladadika quarter used to 
be located outside the city’s 
western walls until these were 
pulled down. Marked as an 
area for wholesale trade close 
to the harbour, it was known 
for its spices and grain shops 
and after 1917 for its olive oil 
storage rooms. Street mapping 
has remained unchanged since 
the late 19th c. and most of 
the buildings – erected mostly 
during the 2nd half of the 19th 
c. – are two-storeyed and were 
constructed using industrial 
brick and wood although 
several were demolished later 
to make way for new streets 
or widen old ones. After

7 	\x07TRADITIONAL

The area west of Aristotelous 
street and south of Egnatia 
Street encompasses the 
town’s traditional market; it 
is dotted with small shops, 
malls and arcades, most of 
which date back to the time 
of the Turkish Occupation. 
Today, in these much visited 
marketplaces, you can find all 
kinds of products – food and 
spices, fabrics, jewellery, small 
boutiques and also tavernas, 
ouzo restaurants and coffee 
shops.

["<1-hop>

42 Thessaloniki’s Old Town is full of atmosphere. It covers the area in between the city walls (to the north and east) and Olympiados Street (to the south), and has had the luck to remain untouched by the 1917 great fire. It was virtually uninhabited until the mid-15th century, when it was conquered by the Ottomans who selected it for settlement on account of its fine climate, panoramic views and strategic position. The two and three-storey houses bear mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements (sachnisia) [Şahniş in turkish]; there are also residences with neoclassical and eclectic style motifs where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews. After 1922 many refugees settled in the area. Despite the construction of newer buildings and the opening up of new streets in recent decades, it has kept its original town planning, to a large extent, with narrow alleys and scant squares, as well as its original architectural features, particularly in the west and east part of the town. This particular atmosphere has lured intellects, artists and students who chose it for settlement in recent years. 1 \x07AGIA AIKATERINI [SAINT CATHERINE] CHURCH (see p. 12) NIKIS NIKIS GERMANOU SVOLOU IASONIDOU TSIMISKI VAS. Roman (Ancient) Forum During the roman period, this 2-hectare area used to be the social and religious centre of the city. Construction was completed in two phases (in the mid-2nd and mid- 3rd centuries AD) and it was gradually abandoned after the 7th century. The NW section of the archaeological site is covered by a large rectangular square [Α] with traces of marble paving. In the S section of the square lies the largest part of the double underground Cryptoporticus [covered passageway] [Β] which was most probably used as a public storehouse. response:
## Historical Significance of Thessaloniki's Old Town

Thessaloniki's Old Town, also known as Ano Poli, is a treasure trove of Macedonian heritage, showcasing a blend of architectural styles and historical narratives that date back centuries. This area has remained largely untouched since the great fire of 1917, preserving its unique character and offering a glimpse into the city's past. The Old Town is characterized by its traditional architecture, including notable structures such as the Profitis Ilias Church and the Panagia Lagoudiani Church, which exemplify Byzantine architectural styles. The remnants of the city's ancient walls and traces of habitation dating back to the 2nd century AD further emphasize its historical importance [Data: Entities (951); Relationships (4)].

The Old Town serves as a cultural hub, reflecting the vibrant local culture with numerous tavernas and café-bars where locals gather to enjoy traditional gastronomy. This neighborhood not only attracts visitors for its scenic views and historical significance but also connects to the broader narrative of Thessaloniki's evolution through various historical epochs, including the Roman period [Data: Entities (4); Relationships (4)].

## Connection to the Roman Forum

The Roman Forum, located in the Historic Centre of Thessaloniki, is a significant archaeological site that played a crucial role during the Roman era as the social and religious center of the city. Constructed between the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD, the Forum served as a public space where various activities took place, including trade, social gatherings, and religious ceremonies [Data: Reports (326); Entities (797)].

The proximity of the Old Town to the Roman Forum highlights the interconnectedness of these historical sites. The Forum's archaeological significance extends to the Old Town, as both areas reflect the rich cultural heritage of Thessaloniki and its evolution through time. The Roman Forum's artifacts and structures contribute to the understanding of the city's historical wealth and artistic achievements, while the Old Town encapsulates the traditional lifestyle and architectural diversity that have persisted through centuries [Data: Reports (326); Relationships (681)].

In summary, Thessaloniki's Old Town holds immense historical significance as a representation of Macedonian heritage, while its connection to the Roman Forum underscores the city's rich tapestry of history, culture, and architectural innovation. The interplay between these two areas offers visitors a comprehensive insight into Thessaloniki's past and its enduring legacy.
reference: Thessaloniki's Old Town is significant for its Macedonian heritage as it showcases a blend of Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements, reflecting the city's diverse history. The area remained largely untouched by the 1917 great fire, preserving its original town planning and atmosphere, which has attracted artists and intellects. Additionally, the Roman Forum, which served as the social and religious center of the city during the Roman period, connects to this heritage as it highlights the city's historical importance from ancient times through the Byzantine era, further enriching the cultural tapestry of Thessaloniki.

["<1-hop>

42 Thessaloniki’s Old Town is full of atmosphere. It covers the area in between the city walls (to the north and east) and Olympiados Street (to the south), and has had the luck to remain untouched by the 1917 great fire. It was virtually uninhabited until the mid-15th century, when it was conquered by the Ottomans who selected it for settlement on account of its fine climate, panoramic views and strategic position. The two and three-storey houses bear mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements (sachnisia) [Şahniş in turkish]; there are also residences with neoclassical and eclectic style motifs where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews. After 1922 many refugees settled in the area. Despite the construction of newer buildings and the opening up of new streets in recent decades, it has kept its original town planning, to a large extent, with narrow alleys and scant squares, as well as its original architectural features, particularly in the west and east part of the town. This particular atmosphere has lured intellects, artists and students who chose it for settlement in recent years. 1 \x07AGIA AIKATERINI [SAINT CATHERINE] CHURCH (see p. 12) NIKIS NIKIS GERMANOU SVOLOU IASONIDOU TSIMISKI VAS. response:
## Historical Significance of Thessaloniki's Old Town

Thessaloniki's Old Town, known as Ano Poli, is a historic district that has preserved much of its architectural heritage since the early 20th century. This area is characterized by its traditional architecture, including notable structures such as the Profitis Ilias Church and the Panagia Lagoudiani Church, which exemplify Byzantine architectural styles. The Old Town is not only significant for its buildings but also for its historical context, as it contains remnants of the city's ancient walls and traces of habitation dating back to the 2nd century AD. This rich tapestry of history makes Ano Poli a vital part of Thessaloniki's cultural identity, reflecting the city's evolution through various historical epochs [Data: Entities (4, 951, 1438)].

The Old Town serves as a vibrant cultural hub, featuring numerous tavernas and café-bars where locals gather to enjoy traditional gastronomy. This local culture enhances the visitor experience, allowing tourists to engage with the city's past while enjoying its contemporary offerings. The panoramic views of Thessaloniki from this district further add to its appeal, making it a picturesque area that connects visitors to the city's historical narrative [Data: Entities (4, 951)].

## Relationship to the Roman Forum

The Roman Forum, located in the Historic Centre of Thessaloniki, is another crucial element of the city's cultural heritage. This ancient public space, which served as the social and religious center during the Roman era, showcases the historical significance of Macedonia. The Forum was constructed between the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD and has been a vital archaeological site that reflects the city's Roman past. It includes various structures such as the Odeon, shops, and remnants of a colonnade, which provide insights into the daily life and social practices of ancient Thessaloniki [Data: Entities (797, 1438); Reports (153)].

The Roman Forum and the Old Town are interconnected through their representation of Macedonia's rich cultural heritage. While the Old Town highlights the Byzantine and Ottoman influences on the city, the Roman Forum emphasizes the earlier Roman contributions to Thessaloniki's development. Together, these sites illustrate the layered history of the region, showcasing how different cultures have shaped the identity of Thessaloniki over centuries. The preservation of both areas allows visitors to appreciate the diverse historical narratives that define this vibrant city [Data: Entities (3, 0, 9); Relationships (298, 313, 681)].

In summary, Thessaloniki's Old Town and the Roman Forum are significant historical sites that reflect the city's multifaceted cultural heritage. They provide a window into the past, allowing visitors to explore the rich tapestry of influences that have shaped Thessaloniki into the vibrant city it is today.
reference: Thessaloniki's Old Town is historically significant as it has remained largely untouched since the 1917 great fire and showcases a blend of Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements. It was settled by the Ottomans in the mid-15th century due to its favorable climate and strategic position. The Roman Forum, on the other hand, served as the social and religious center of the city during the Roman period, with construction completed in the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD. Both sites reflect the rich cultural heritage of Macedonia, illustrating the city's evolution through different historical periods and influences.

user_input: What historical significance does Thessaloniki's Old Town hold in relation to its Macedonian heritage, and how does this connect to the Roman Forum's role in the city's development?

to the city and it was at that 
time situated outside the 
east walls (Cassander’s Gate). 
During the Interwar Period a 
large part of it was removed 
to make Egnatia Street wider; 
it was restored to its original 
shape in 1977.
2 	\x07ARISTOTLE 
UNIVERSITY OF 
THESSALONIKI (AUTH).
This is the first University 
Campus in Greece (covering 
a 50 hectare area) to have 
been built following complete 
architectural plans. It was 
planned to be constructed 
on the location of the old 
Jewish cemetery (see p. 61), 
according to the Hébrard 
committee plan; construction 
finally began in 1938, yet the 
works were interrupted during 
the war and resumed in the 
1950s. Since then, several 
buildings were erected on 
these grounds by leading', ' a major Greek 
architect, and it was 
inaugurated in 1962. Inspired 
by the ancient Greek Revival 
Architectural style, it is 
considered as one of the most 
typical examples of modernist 
architectural design in Greece. 
An annex was added in 1980 
and in 2003 the museum  
was extensively remodelled  
to accommodate contemporary 
needs. There are rooms for 
periodic exhibitions, events 
and educational programmes, 
a café and a shop (see p.70  
for museum exhibits).  
1.7  Museum of Byzantine 
Culture.
It was built during the 
years 1989 – 1993, following 
the designs of architect K. 
Krokos. It combines elements 
of modernism and Greek 
architectural tradition and it 
is considered one of the best 
contemporary constructions 
meant for public use in Greece.  
In 2001 it was declared a 
listed historic monument and  
a work of art. Inside there is  
a small amphitheatre, a café-
restaurant and a wing for 
hosting periodic exhibitions 
(see p. 71 for museum 
exhibits). The adjacent 
building is the new Town Hall 
(inaugurated in 2009); at the 
back there is a park (formerly 
named Pedion Areos, a section 
of an old military camp), with 
a playground, a small lake and 
23.  
The Y.M.C.A. 
building. 
Notice the 
neo-byzantine 
architectural 
elements.
24.  
A panoramic 
view of the 
Archaeological 
Museum of 
Thessaloniki.

10.2 OTE [Hellenic 
Telecommunications 
Organisation] Tower.
It was built in 1969 to plans 
by architect Al. Anastasiadis, 
as the Organisation’s 
exhibition pavilion, and for 
covering the city’s telecom 
needs. It dominates against 
the city’s horizon as it reaches 
a 70-metre height – including 
the antenna. Its storeys house 
radio stations and at a higher 
level there is a caffé with a 
rotating floor (completes a 
revolution in 70 min.), where 
the city and seafront views 
are amazing. At a very short 
distance lies the Radio 
Museum which is worth your 
visit (see the exhibits on p. 78).
10.3 Alexandreio 
Melathron.
Also known as Palais des 
Sports, this sports arena is 
located on the NE side of the 
Thessaloniki International Fair 
grounds. Constructed in 1966, 
it has played an active part 
in Thessaloniki’s history ever 
since, as major sporting, art 
as well as political events have 
taken place in it over the years.  
It is a round edifice with a 
seating for 4,800, and it used 
to be the largest indoor sports 
arena in Greece until 1985. 
Today, it is the home ground of 
Aris basketball team.
10', ' the city.
3.7  Ataturk Museum.
It is adjacent to the building 
of the Turkish consulate (75, Ap. 
Pavlou St.). This three-storey 
residence was built in the late 
19th c. and it was the house  
of Kemal Ataturk, born  
in Thessaloniki (1880? - 1938). 
In the yard, you will see  
a pomegranate tree his father  
had planted there. It is a building 
now painted in its original colour 
- pink – and houses  
40 & 41.

house (left) 
is a museum 
nowadays and 
houses an 
atmospheric 
café (right).
42.

Stadium is the 
largest one in 
the city.

Turkish state. To visit it you need

3.8  Teloglion Foundation 
of Art. 
Built on elevated ground in 
the north side of the Campus, 
it is a modern building complex 
covering a 3,200 m2 area and 
it was inaugurated in 1998. 
There are spatious exhibition 
areas, an amphitheatre,  
a library – reading room,  
as well as rooms for research 
and educational programmes, 
a shop and a café-restaurant  
(for the foundation’s collections 
see p. 76). Thessaloniki’s 
National Swimming Pool  
is located east of Teloglion.

It was built in 1960, following', '

3.1  Kalapothaki Street.
It starts at Ladadika area, 
ends at Dimosthenous 
street and its biggest part is 
now pedestrianised. There 
are some very interesting 
neoclassical and Bauhaus-

cafés, bar restaurants, and 
small hotels. Stein Building is 
at the corner of El. Venizelos 
and Kalapothaki Streets; it 
was built in 1908 in order to

and it is one of the very few 
buildings that were spared 
destruction at the 1917 great 
fire. Notice the glass globe on 
the top of the building, a point 
of reference in Eleftherias Sq. 
In the neighbouring Komninon 
Street it is worth noticing the 
eclectic style on buildings 
such as Luxemburg Hotel as 
well as Tourist and Excelsior 
Hotels at the junction with 
Mitropoleos streets.
4 	PORT
The area is one of the biggest 
ports of the country and of the 
southeastern Mediterranean, 
with a significant trade and 
passenger traffic. This is where 
the first artificial harbour of 
the town was constructed by 
Constantine the Great during 
his short stay in Thessaloniki 
(322-323 AD); later on during 
the Turkish Occupation it 
was banked up with earth.

boutiques and also tavernas,

["<1-hop>

42 Thessaloniki’s Old Town is full of atmosphere. It covers the area in between the city walls (to the north and east) and Olympiados Street (to the south), and has had the luck to remain untouched by the 1917 great fire. It was virtually uninhabited until the mid-15th century, when it was conquered by the Ottomans who selected it for settlement on account of its fine climate, panoramic views and strategic position. The two and three-storey houses bear mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements (sachnisia) [Şahniş in turkish]; there are also residences with neoclassical and eclectic style motifs where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews. After 1922 many refugees settled in the area. Despite the construction of newer buildings and the opening up of new streets in recent decades, it has kept its original town planning, to a large extent, with narrow alleys and scant squares, as well as its original architectural features, particularly in the west and east part of the town. This particular atmosphere has lured intellects, artists and students who chose it for settlement in recent years. 1 \x07AGIA AIKATERINI [SAINT CATHERINE] CHURCH (see p. 12) NIKIS NIKIS GERMANOU SVOLOU IASONIDOU TSIMISKI VAS. Roman (Ancient) Forum During the roman period, this 2-hectare area used to be the social and religious centre of the city. Construction was completed in two phases (in the mid-2nd and mid- 3rd centuries AD) and it was gradually abandoned after the 7th century. The NW section of the archaeological site is covered by a large rectangular square [Α] with traces of marble paving. In the S section of the square lies the largest part of the double underground Cryptoporticus [covered passageway] [Β] which was most probably used as a public storehouse. response:
## Historical Significance of Thessaloniki's Old Town

Thessaloniki's Old Town, also known as Ano Poli, is a treasure trove of Macedonian heritage, showcasing the city's rich historical tapestry. This area has remained largely untouched since the devastating fire of 1917, preserving its unique architectural styles that reflect the Byzantine and Ottoman influences. The Old Town is characterized by its traditional buildings, narrow streets, and stunning views of the city, making it a significant cultural and historical district. It serves as a reminder of Thessaloniki's evolution through various historical epochs, particularly during the Byzantine and Ottoman periods, which have shaped its identity [Data: Entities (4, 951); Relationships (270)].

The Old Town is not only a residential area but also a cultural hub where local traditions thrive. It features numerous tavernas and cafés that offer a glimpse into the local lifestyle, further enhancing its appeal to visitors interested in experiencing authentic Macedonian culture. The remnants of ancient walls and historical churches, such as the Profitis Ilias Church, add to the area's historical significance, connecting visitors to the city's past [Data: Entities (4); Relationships (270)].

## Connection to the Roman Forum

The Roman Forum, located in the heart of Thessaloniki, plays a crucial role in understanding the city's development and its historical significance. This ancient public space served as the social and religious center during the Roman era, showcasing the city's importance as a major urban center in Macedonia. Constructed between the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD, the Roman Forum was a vibrant hub of activity, featuring shops, public buildings, and cultural events that reflected the city's prosperity during the Roman Empire [Data: Entities (797); Relationships (681)].

The connection between the Old Town and the Roman Forum lies in their shared historical narrative. Both areas highlight Thessaloniki's multicultural background and its significance as a crossroads of various civilizations, including the Romans, Byzantines, and Ottomans. The Roman Forum's archaeological significance extends the Historic Centre of Thessaloniki, providing insights into the city's past and its architectural evolution. The Forum's remnants, including colonnades and public spaces, illustrate the city's development over centuries and its role as a vital center of commerce and culture in Macedonia [Data: Entities (3, 797); Relationships (681)].

## Conclusion

In summary, Thessaloniki's Old Town and the Roman Forum are integral to understanding the city's Macedonian heritage. The Old Town preserves the cultural and architectural legacy of the region, while the Roman Forum serves as a testament to Thessaloniki's historical significance during the Roman Empire. Together, they encapsulate the rich history of Thessaloniki, reflecting its evolution and the diverse influences that have shaped its identity over the centuries [Data: Entities (4, 3, 797); Relationships (270, 681)].
reference: Thessaloniki's Old Town is significant for its Macedonian heritage as it showcases a blend of Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements, reflecting the city's diverse history. The area remained largely untouched by the 1917 great fire, preserving its original town planning and architectural features. This historical context is further enriched by the Roman Forum, which served as the social and religious center of the city during the Roman period. Constructed in the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD, the Forum highlights the city's importance in the region and its evolution over time, linking the Macedonian past with the Roman influence that shaped Thessaloniki's development.

user_input: What historical significance does the Roman Forum in Thessaloniki hold in relation to the city's Macedonian heritage?

that is indicative of the ground 
level 2000 years ago.

THE ROMAN FORUM 
MUSEUM
Small yet very interesting, 
this museum was inaugurated 
in 2010. A narrative of local 
excavations and information 
on the museum’s building 
stages is on display in the 
vestibule; in the main hall, 
visitors will see a depiction 
of the area’s history from the 
Hellenistic years until the 4th 
c. AD. Other exhibits of great 
interest are the Hellenistic 
Bathhouse, the ancient brothel, 
and the fountain associated 
with the Stoa of the Statuettes 
(Las Incantadas). There are 
also finds related to the period 
from the Turkish Occupation 
until the 1917 fire. Next to 
exhibited items, there are 
descriptive texts and photos.
MUSEUM OF BYZANTINE 
CULTURE
It is considered one of the 
best museums in Greece and 
ranks high among its peers 
across the globe, offering 
a detailed picture of the 
Byzantine culture. Among 
the 2,900 masterpieces of 
exhibits, there are murals, 
mosaics, icons, marble 
architectural members, whole 
Early Christian tombs, church 
vessels, items of personal 
dress, as well as objects of 
everyday use and tools used

Thessaloniki’s gastronomy 
can boast some pretty 
impressive delicacies 
[mezedes] such as gyro [slices

features the renowned syrupy

The city’s centuries-old multicultural history has been 
associated with great empires, as it has known the 
Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman Rule. The town was also 
greatly influenced by many ethnic and religious groups 
(Jews, Latins, Armenians and others) as well as Greeks 
from Constantinople, Pontus [modern-day northeastern 
Turkey] and Asia Minor [a.k.a. Anatolia]. The numerous 
monuments, dating to many historical periods, coexist in 
a singular and charming way and manifest Thessaloniki’s 
historical multicultural and cosmopolitan nature.

Thessaloniki’s location is at the centre of a greater area 
with incomparable historical monuments and natural assets 
as it offers the opportunity for a visit to archaeological 
sites known the world over (Ancient Pella, Vergina, Dion, 
Petralona Cave), to areas of exquisite nature (river deltas, 
lakes, Mt Olympus), to the monastic state of Agion Oros 
[the Holy Mountain] as well as to Halkidiki, a famous tourist 
destination. And there is always an opportunity to practice 
sports (swimming, skiing, playing golf etc) or to indulge in 
wellness tourism (hot springs, spas)!
In short, Thessaloniki is a city that can cater for even the 
most demanding needs, any time of the year.

42 Thessaloniki’s Old Town is full of atmosphere. It covers the area in between the city walls (to the north and east) and Olympiados Street (to the south), and has had the luck to remain untouched by the 1917 great fire. It was virtually uninhabited until the mid-15th century, when it was conquered by the Ottomans who selected it for settlement on account of its fine climate, panoramic views and strategic position. The two and three-storey houses bear mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements (sachnisia) [Şahniş in turkish]; there are also residences with neoclassical and eclectic style motifs where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews. After 1922 many refugees settled in the area. Despite the construction of newer buildings and the opening up of new streets in recent decades, it has kept its original town planning, to a large extent, with narrow alleys and scant squares, as well as its original architectural features, particularly in the west and east part of the town. This particular atmosphere has lured intellects, artists and students who chose it for settlement in recent years. 1 \x07AGIA AIKATERINI [SAINT CATHERINE] CHURCH (see p. 12) NIKIS NIKIS GERMANOU SVOLOU IASONIDOU TSIMISKI VAS. response:
## Historical Significance of the Roman Forum in Thessaloniki

The Roman Forum in Thessaloniki is a pivotal site that encapsulates the rich historical and cultural heritage of Macedonia. Established during the Roman period, it served as the social and religious center of the city, reflecting the architectural and urban planning of the time. The forum was constructed between the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD and played a crucial role in the daily life of Thessaloniki, showcasing the city's importance within the Roman Empire [Data: Sources (70), Entities (797)].

### Architectural and Cultural Hub

The Roman Forum is not just an archaeological site; it is a cultural hub that highlights the evolution of Thessaloniki through various historical epochs. The forum features significant structures, including the Stoa of the Statuettes and the Odeon, which were integral to the social fabric of the city. These structures provide insights into the architectural ingenuity of the Hellenistic and Roman periods, showcasing the aesthetic values and technological advancements of the time [Data: Reports (153), Relationships (681)].

### Connection to Macedonian Heritage

Thessaloniki, as the historic capital of Macedonia, has deep connections to the region's heritage. The Roman Forum Museum, which houses artifacts from the forum, exhibits aspects of Macedonia's history from the Hellenistic period to the 4th century AD. This museum serves as a vital resource for understanding the historical context of Macedonia, preserving artifacts that reflect the region's rich cultural narrative [Data: Entities (1438), Relationships (1565)].

### Educational and Economic Impact

The Roman Forum and its associated museum play a significant role in promoting local history and cultural appreciation. By showcasing various aspects of ancient Macedonian life, including social practices and architectural features, the forum attracts visitors interested in ancient lifestyles. This not only contributes to the educational mission of the museum but also enhances the economic viability of tourism in the area [Data: Reports (153), Entities (797)].

In summary, the Roman Forum in Thessaloniki is a cornerstone of the city's Macedonian heritage, representing a blend of historical significance, architectural beauty, and cultural richness. Its preservation and presentation through the Roman Forum Museum ensure that the legacy of Macedonia continues to be appreciated by both locals and visitors alike [Data: Sources (70), Reports (153)].
reference: The Roman Forum in Thessaloniki, which served as the social and religious center of the city during the Roman period, reflects the city's Macedonian heritage. Constructed in two phases during the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD, it showcases the architectural and cultural influences of the time. The forum was gradually abandoned after the 7th century, but its remnants, including a large rectangular square and the double underground Cryptoporticus, highlight the historical significance of Thessaloniki as a key location in Macedonia.

10.2 OTE [Hellenic 
Telecommunications 
Organisation] Tower.
It was built in 1969 to plans 
by architect Al. Anastasiadis, 
as the Organisation’s 
exhibition pavilion, and for 
covering the city’s telecom 
needs. It dominates against 
the city’s horizon as it reaches 
a 70-metre height – including 
the antenna. Its storeys house 
radio stations and at a higher 
level there is a caffé with a 
rotating floor (completes a 
revolution in 70 min.), where 
the city and seafront views 
are amazing. At a very short 
distance lies the Radio 
Museum which is worth your 
visit (see the exhibits on p. 78).
10.3 Alexandreio 
Melathron.
Also known as Palais des 
Sports, this sports arena is 
located on the NE side of the 
Thessaloniki International Fair 
grounds. Constructed in 1966, 
it has played an active part 
in Thessaloniki’s history ever 
since, as major sporting, art 
as well as political events have 
taken place in it over the years.  
It is a round edifice with a 
seating for 4,800, and it used 
to be the largest indoor sports 
arena in Greece until 1985. 
Today, it is the home ground of 
Aris basketball team.
10', ' the city.
3.7  Ataturk Museum.
It is adjacent to the building 
of the Turkish consulate (75, Ap. 
Pavlou St.). This three-storey 
residence was built in the late 
19th c. and it was the house  
of Kemal Ataturk, born  
in Thessaloniki (1880? - 1938). 
In the yard, you will see  
a pomegranate tree his father  
had planted there. It is a building 
now painted in its original colour 
- pink – and houses  
40 & 41.

house (left) 
is a museum 
nowadays and 
houses an 
atmospheric 
café (right).
42. 
Kaftanzogleio 
Stadium is the 
largest one in 
the city.

Teloglion 
Foundation  
of Art.

a small museum dedicated 
to the founder of the modern 
Turkish state. To visit it you need 
an identity card or passport  
(for museum exhibits, see p. 74).
3.8  Teloglion Foundation 
of Art. 
Built on elevated ground in 
the north side of the Campus, 
it is a modern building complex 
covering a 3,200 m2 area and 
it was inaugurated in 1998. 
There are spatious exhibition 
areas, an amphitheatre,  
a library – reading room,  
as well as rooms for research 
and educational programmes, 
a shop and a café-restaurant  
(for the foundation’s collections 
see p. 76). Thessaloniki’s 
National Swimming Pool  
is located east of Teloglion. 
3.9  Kaftanzogleio Stadium.
It was built in 1960, following', ' 
Bank of Greece & the Bank 
of Greece (1928) and of the 
Ionian and Popular Bank (1929 
– today Alpha Bank); elements 
of late neoclassicism and 
interwar period eclecticism are 
evident on the outside of both 
buildings.
MUST SEE:
3.1  Kalapothaki Street.
It starts at Ladadika area, 
ends at Dimosthenous 
street and its biggest part is 
now pedestrianised. There 
are some very interesting 
neoclassical and Bauhaus-
style buildings with popular 
cafés, bar restaurants, and 
small hotels. Stein Building is 
at the corner of El. Venizelos 
and Kalapothaki Streets; it 
was built in 1908 in order to 
house a department store 
and it is one of the very few 
buildings that were spared 
destruction at the 1917 great 
fire. Notice the glass globe on 
the top of the building, a point 
of reference in Eleftherias Sq. 
In the neighbouring Komninon 
Street it is worth noticing the 
eclectic style on buildings 
such as Luxemburg Hotel as 
well as Tourist and Excelsior 
Hotels at the junction with 
Mitropoleos streets.
4 	PORT
The area is one of the biggest 
ports of the country and of the 
southeastern Mediterranean, 
with a significant trade and 
passenger traffic. This is where 
the first artificial harbour of 
the town was constructed by 
Constantine the Great during 
his short stay in Thessaloniki 
(322-323 AD); later on during 
the Turkish Occupation it 
was banked up with earth.

This is one of the very few

was created in the 16th c. 
when the Turks banked the

up with earth, and ended in 
Fragkomachalas area (see p. 
22); Ladadika quarter used to 
be located outside the city’s 
western walls until these were 
pulled down. Marked as an 
area for wholesale trade close 
to the harbour, it was known 
for its spices and grain shops 
and after 1917 for its olive oil 
storage rooms. Street mapping 
has remained unchanged since 
the late 19th c. and most of 
the buildings – erected mostly 
during the 2nd half of the 19th 
c. – are two-storeyed and were 
constructed using industrial 
brick and wood although 
several were demolished later 
to make way for new streets 
or widen old ones. After

is dotted with small shops, 
malls and arcades, most of 
which date back to the time 
of the Turkish Occupation. 
Today, in these much visited 
marketplaces, you can find all 
kinds of products – food and 
spices, fabrics, jewellery, small 
boutiques and also tavernas, 
ouzo restaurants and coffee 
shops.

["<1-hop>

42 Thessaloniki’s Old Town is full of atmosphere. It covers the area in between the city walls (to the north and east) and Olympiados Street (to the south), and has had the luck to remain untouched by the 1917 great fire. It was virtually uninhabited until the mid-15th century, when it was conquered by the Ottomans who selected it for settlement on account of its fine climate, panoramic views and strategic position. The two and three-storey houses bear mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements (sachnisia) [Şahniş in turkish]; there are also residences with neoclassical and eclectic style motifs where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews. After 1922 many refugees settled in the area. Despite the construction of newer buildings and the opening up of new streets in recent decades, it has kept its original town planning, to a large extent, with narrow alleys and scant squares, as well as its original architectural features, particularly in the west and east part of the town. This particular atmosphere has lured intellects, artists and students who chose it for settlement in recent years. 1 \x07AGIA AIKATERINI [SAINT CATHERINE] CHURCH (see p. 12) NIKIS NIKIS GERMANOU SVOLOU IASONIDOU TSIMISKI VAS. Roman (Ancient) Forum During the roman period, this 2-hectare area used to be the social and religious centre of the city. Construction was completed in two phases (in the mid-2nd and mid- 3rd centuries AD) and it was gradually abandoned after the 7th century. The NW section of the archaeological site is covered by a large rectangular square [Α] with traces of marble paving. In the S section of the square lies the largest part of the double underground Cryptoporticus [covered passageway] [Β] which was most probably used as a public storehouse. response:
## Historical Significance of Thessaloniki's Old Town

Thessaloniki's Old Town, known as Ano Poli, is a remarkable area that encapsulates the city's rich historical narrative and architectural diversity. This district has remained largely untouched since the devastating fire of 1917, preserving a unique blend of architectural styles that reflect the city's multicultural heritage. The Old Town features a mix of Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements, showcasing the influences of various cultures that have shaped Thessaloniki over the centuries.

### Architectural Styles

The architectural landscape of Ano Poli is characterized by its traditional two and three-storey houses, which exhibit a combination of Macedonian and Ottoman styles. The structures, often referred to as "sachnisia," are notable for their distinctive features that highlight the region's historical evolution. The area is also home to significant Byzantine architectural remnants, including churches that date back to the early Christian period, further emphasizing the rich tapestry of influences that define Thessaloniki's Old Town [Data: Entities (951); Relationships (765)].

### Influence of the Ottoman Period

During the Ottoman period, Thessaloniki was a vital city within the empire, and this influence is evident in the architectural styles found in the Old Town. The Ottomans selected this area for settlement due to its strategic position and favorable climate, leading to the construction of various buildings that reflect their architectural preferences. The harmonious coexistence of different ethnic and religious communities during this time contributed to the cultural richness of the Old Town, making it a significant site for understanding the complexities of Thessaloniki's history [Data: Entities (17); Relationships (11)].

### Cultural Heritage

The Old Town not only serves as a historical landmark but also as a vibrant cultural hub where local traditions and modern life intersect. The area is dotted with tavernas and café-bars that offer a glimpse into the local gastronomy, allowing visitors to experience the flavors of Thessaloniki while enjoying the scenic views of the city. This blend of history and contemporary culture makes Ano Poli a must-visit destination for those interested in exploring the city's past and its ongoing cultural narrative [Data: Entities (4); Relationships (270)].

In summary, Thessaloniki's Old Town holds significant historical importance as a testament to the city's architectural diversity and the lasting influence of Macedonian and Ottoman cultures. Its preservation of traditional styles and vibrant local culture makes it a key area for understanding Thessaloniki's rich heritage and historical significance [Data: Entities (3); Relationships (298)].
reference: Thessaloniki's Old Town is historically significant as it showcases a blend of architectural styles that reflect its Macedonian heritage and the influence of the Ottoman period. The area, which remained largely untouched by the 1917 great fire, features two and three-storey houses that exhibit mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements, known as sachnisia. This unique combination of styles, along with neoclassical and eclectic motifs, highlights the town's rich cultural history. The settlement of the Ottomans in the mid-15th century, attracted by the region's fine climate and strategic position, further contributed to the architectural landscape, making it a vibrant center for intellects, artists, and students in recent years.

also a vaulted tank for heating 
water. It is widely known as the 
Paradise Baths and it went by 
that name until 1968. Right next 
to it there is a roman platform 
that is indicative of the ground 
level 2000 years ago.
1.6  Roman (Ancient) Forum
During the roman period, 
this 2-hectare area used to be 
the social and religious centre 
of the city. Construction was 
completed in two phases  
(in the mid-2nd and mid-  
3rd centuries AD) and it was 
gradually abandoned after the 
7th century. The NW section 
of', '

that the place had been used 
by Christians as well, during 
the late Roman period. South 
of the passageway there 
were shops dating from the 
1st until the 13th century; the 
underground Museum of the 
Roman Forum (see p. 71) was 
built there as an extension. 
A 2nd - 4th c. AD Odeon [C] 
was found behind the well-
preserved eastern stoa. It  
has been restored and it is now 
used as a venue for cultural 
events. A mint and an archive 
office are right next to it. In the 
SE side, a round bath house 
[D] was unearthed which has 
been in use since the 1st c. BC. 
Parts of a colonnade, mosaic 
floors, marble stairs, a section 
of a stone-paved street, sewer 
pipes, silver coins, stone and 
marble sculptures were all 
found in this archaeological 
site. The forum is also where 
the “Enchanted Ones” (las 
Incantadas) were discovered, 
a two-storeyed colonnaded 
archway with Corinthian-order 
columns and pillars four of 
which have survived. They are 
decorated with figures in relief 
in their interior as well as their 
exterior side (“Stoa of the 
Statuettes”). It is estimated 
that the Stoa’s location was 
at the south entrance to the 
forum (from Egnatia Street);  
in 1864 the pillars were 
removed and escorted to their 
present location at the Louvre 
Museum (Paris) by E. Miller.

Small Market place) is a spot

THE ROMAN FORUM 
MUSEUM
Small yet very interesting, 
this museum was inaugurated 
in 2010. A narrative of local 
excavations and information 
on the museum’s building 
stages is on display in the 
vestibule; in the main hall, 
visitors will see a depiction 
of the area’s history from the 
Hellenistic years until the 4th 
c. AD. Other exhibits of great 
interest are the Hellenistic 
Bathhouse, the ancient brothel, 
and the fountain associated 
with the Stoa of the Statuettes 
(Las Incantadas). There are 
also finds related to the period 
from the Turkish Occupation 
until the 1917 fire. Next to 
exhibited items, there are 
descriptive texts and photos.
MUSEUM OF BYZANTINE 
CULTURE
It is considered one of the 
best museums in Greece and 
ranks high among its peers 
across the globe, offering 
a detailed picture of the 
Byzantine culture. Among 
the 2,900 masterpieces of 
exhibits, there are murals, 
mosaics, icons, marble 
architectural members, whole 
Early Christian tombs, church 
vessels, items of personal 
dress, as well as objects of 
everyday use and tools used

the Byzantine everyday life, 
art and culture are depicted, 
covering the times from 
the early Byzantine until 
the post Byzantine period. 
The exhibition is structured

This structure - square

TOURING THESSALONIKI
WITH CHILDREN
Thessaloniki’s relatively 
small size - for a city – 
makes it a particularly friendly 
place for children and offers a 
host of activities for them. 
Go on a bicycle ride 
along the town’s bike lanes, 
especially by the waterfront, 
starting from the harbour 
(see p. 17), past the White 
Tower area (see p. 24) and up 
to the Concert Hall (see p. 52) 
or visit the Theme Parks of 
the new (east) seafront [Nea 
Anatoliki Paralia] (see p. 50) 
where there are playgrounds 
Thessaloniki Wines. 
Macedonia has a long 
tradition on wine-making, 
as the district can boast 
some of the most renowned 
Greek vineyards. In the area 
surrounding the town, a wide 
range of varieties are grown 
such as Roditis, Asyrtiko, 
Malagouzia, Sauvignon 
Blanc, Chardonnay, Voignier, 
Syrah, Merlot, Grenache 
Rouge, Limnio, Mavroudi, 
Mavrotragano, Xinomavro, 
Cabernet Sauvignon, Athiri and 
Malvasia. The Wine Producers 
Association of Northern 
Greece Vineyards, under the 
trade name Wines of Northern 
Greece, realises a programme 
titled “Wine', ' Towards the birth of towns. 
(ground floor, room 4). The 
evidence on display shows 
that there were settlements in 
Macedonia dating to the Iron 
Age, from 1100 to 700 BC.
• Macedonia from the 7th c.  
BC until Late Antiquity. 
(ground floor, room 5). Eight 
large theme sections cover 
various aspects of private 
and public life in Macedonia 
from the archaic years, when 
the independent Macedonian 
kingdom was created, until 
the 1st – 4th c. AD, when the 
entire region was a province 
of the Roman Empire. Finds 
come mainly from excavations 
carried out in areas of central 
Macedonia.
• Thessaloniki, Metropolis 
of Macedonia. (ground 
floor, room 6). Historical and 
archaeological information 
is presented, starting from 
315 BC when the town was 
founded. There is also a 
partial reconstruction of an 
archaic temple of Ionic order, 
whose original position is yet 
unknown; it was transported 
to the area of the Temples of 
Thessaloniki during the Roman 
occupation.
• The gold of Macedon. 
(ground floor, room 7). It 
includes exhibits of exceptional 
craftsmanship (e.x. diadems, 
crowns, rings, bracelets, 
earrings) removed mostly from 
cemeteries of the archaic and 
classical times; there is also  
a step by step depiction of the 
processing of noble metals. 
The museum owns a very large 
collection of gold crowns; 
particularly worthy of notice 
are also two singular items, the 
crater [type of vase-like vessel] 
and the papyrus of Derveni  
(4th c. BC).
• Field-House-Garden-
Grave. (', ' kept its urban character and has 
remained a civic centre and the hub of that region. 
The city’s centuries-old multicultural history has been 
associated with great empires, as it has known the 
Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman Rule. The town was also 
greatly influenced by many ethnic and religious groups 
(Jews, Latins, Armenians and others) as well as Greeks 
from Constantinople, Pontus [modern-day northeastern 
Turkey] and Asia Minor [a.k.a. Anatolia]. The numerous 
monuments, dating to many historical periods, coexist in 
a singular and charming way and manifest Thessaloniki’s 
historical multicultural and cosmopolitan nature.

«…There is a homeland for everyone,  
while there is Thessaloniki»
Nikiforos Choumnos, 
14thc. Byzantine dignitary and a scholar.
Nowadays, the historic capital -by right- of Macedonia, 
the land of Alexander the Great, has evolved into a modern 
and particularly charming metropolis. A multitide of 
monuments and cultural assets and the town’s traditional 
ways exist in harmony with the modern aspects and the 
high standard infrastructure, the carefree mood, the spirit 
of hospitality, the vitality of the locals – particularly the 
young – setting the pace of town life, the diversity of 
artistic events, the long list of choices for entertainment, 
the exceptional culinary tradition, and the fresh feel in 
the atmosphere, coming from the seafront, as', ' area of

and deserted. Plans are made

(see p. 75). Until this is done, 
locals use the place as a venue 
for various events and there is 
also a library, a reading room 
and a café. At a short distance 
you can visit one of the very 
few remaining macedonian 
tombs (3rd c. BC) that were 
unearthed in the town at the 
corner of Papanastasiou and 
Omirou Sts., as well as the 
remarkable 1891 neoclassical 
edifice of Ippokrateio Hospital 
at 49, Konstantinoupoleos St.

as well as some of the city’s

 42 BC:

Apostle Paul’s first visit  
to the town. He came back

 Late 3rd – early 4th c. AD:	
Becomes the seat of  
the eastern section of the 
Roman Empire [according  
to the system of Tetrarchia – 
(meaning “leadership of four 
men”)] under ceasar Galerius 
Maximianus.
 323 BC:	
Constantine, the first 
emperor of Byzantium settles 
in town in order to wage war 
on Licinius.
 Late 4th AD:	
The town becomes  
the administrative centre  
of Macedonia; Byzantine 
emperor Theodosius builds  
the fortifications of Thessaloniki. 
 5th - 12th c.:	
Raids by Goths, Persians, 
Arabs, Turks and Bulgarians. 
The town is spared destruction 
thanks to its massive walls. 
 1185:	
The Norsemen occupy 
Thessaloniki.
 1224:	
After the 20-year Frankish 
domination of Thessaloniki, 
the town is taken by Theodore 
Komnenos Doukas and is 
declared the capital of the 
Despotate of Epirus.
 1300-1430:	
The golden age of the 
town involves great financial, 
social and intellectual growth. 
Some of the most significant 
monuments, built at that time, 
still stand today.
 1342-1349:	
The Zealot Movement 
prevails as a reaction to 
medieval hegemonism  
and the reign “by the grace  
of God”.

(basement, room 11). The

and 2-5 minor ones, where

THE ROMAN FORUM 
MUSEUM
Small yet very', ' particularly the 
young – setting the pace of town life, the diversity of 
artistic events, the long list of choices for entertainment, 
the exceptional culinary tradition, and the fresh feel in 
the atmosphere, coming from the seafront, as well as the 
coolness of the northwest wind called Vardaris.   
Thessaloniki’s location is at the centre of a greater area 
with incomparable historical monuments and natural assets 
as it offers the opportunity for a visit to archaeological 
sites known the world over (Ancient Pella, Vergina, Dion, 
Petralona Cave), to areas of exquisite nature (river deltas, 
lakes, Mt Olympus), to the monastic state of Agion Oros 
[the Holy Mountain] as well as to Halkidiki, a famous tourist 
destination. And there is always an opportunity to practice 
sports (swimming, skiing, playing golf etc) or to indulge in 
wellness tourism (hot springs, spas)!
In short, Thessaloniki is a city that can cater for even the 
most demanding needs, any time of the year.

You will find choice traditional 
products here and a number of 
particularly popular restaurants 
inside the complex as well as 
along the perimeter.

side of Aristotelous street,

of the Turkish Occupation.

42 Thessaloniki’s Old Town is full of atmosphere. It covers the area in between the city walls (to the north and east) and Olympiados Street (to the south), and has had the luck to remain untouched by the 1917 great fire. It was virtually uninhabited until the mid-15th century, when it was conquered by the Ottomans who selected it for settlement on account of its fine climate, panoramic views and strategic position. The two and three-storey houses bear mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements (sachnisia) [Şahniş in turkish]; there are also residences with neoclassical and eclectic style motifs where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews. After 1922 many refugees settled in the area. Despite the construction of newer buildings and the opening up of new streets in recent decades, it has kept its original town planning, to a large extent, with narrow alleys and scant squares, as well as its original architectural features, particularly in the west and east part of the town. This particular atmosphere has lured intellects, artists and students who chose it for settlement in recent years. 1 \x07AGIA AIKATERINI [SAINT CATHERINE] CHURCH (see p. 12) NIKIS NIKIS GERMANOU SVOLOU IASONIDOU TSIMISKI VAS. ## Historical Significance of the Roman Forum in Thessaloniki

The Roman Forum in Thessaloniki is a site of immense historical importance, serving as a central public space during the Roman period. Established between the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD, it functioned as the social and religious heart of the city, reflecting the architectural and cultural practices of the time. The forum encompassed an area of 2 hectares and was gradually abandoned after the 7th century, but its remnants continue to provide insights into the urban life of ancient Thessaloniki [Data: Entities (797); Relationships (681)].

The forum is notable for its various architectural features, including the Stoa of the Statuettes, which housed the Fountain of Las Incantadas, a significant example of Hellenistic architectural ingenuity. This fountain not only served as a visual centerpiece but also symbolized the cultural richness of ancient Macedonia [Data: Reports (153); Relationships (1568)]. The Roman Forum is also linked to the broader historical narrative of Macedonia, which has been shaped by various civilizations, including the Romans, Byzantines, and Ottomans, each leaving their mark on the region's architectural landscape [Data: Entities (9); Relationships (1549)].

## Architectural Influences in Macedonia

Macedonia's architectural heritage is a tapestry woven from its diverse historical influences. The Roman Forum exemplifies the integration of Roman architectural styles with local traditions, showcasing elements such as colonnades, public baths, and marketplaces that were characteristic of Roman urban planning. The forum's design reflects the social and civic priorities of the time, emphasizing public interaction and community engagement [Data: Reports (153); Entities (797)].

Moreover, the architectural significance of the Roman Forum is complemented by other historical sites in Macedonia, such as the Palace of Galerius and the Archaeological Museum of Thessaloniki, which further illustrate the region's rich cultural heritage. These sites collectively highlight the evolution of architectural styles from the Hellenistic period through the Roman Empire and into the Byzantine era, showcasing a blend of influences that define Macedonia's historical identity [Data: Entities (435, 649); Relationships (1558)].

In summary, the Roman Forum in Thessaloniki stands as a testament to the city's historical significance and its role as a cultural hub in ancient Macedonia. Its architectural features not only reflect Roman influences but also contribute to the broader narrative of Macedonia's rich and diverse heritage, making it a vital site for understanding the region's past [Data: Reports (153); Entities (9, 797)].
reference: The Roman Forum in Thessaloniki, which served as the social and religious center of the city during the Roman period, showcases significant historical importance as it was constructed in two phases during the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD. This area reflects the architectural influences of the time, which can also be seen in the mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements present in Thessaloniki’s Old Town. The forum's gradual abandonment after the 7th century and the remnants of its structures, such as the double underground Cryptoporticus, highlight the city's rich historical tapestry, which is deeply intertwined with the broader architectural heritage of Macedonia.

The city’s centuries-old multicultural history has been 
associated with great empires, as it has known the 
Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman Rule. The town was also 
greatly influenced by many ethnic and religious groups 
(Jews, Latins, Armenians and others) as well as Greeks 
from Constantinople, Pontus [modern-day northeastern 
Turkey] and Asia Minor [a.k.a. Anatolia]. The numerous 
monuments, dating to many historical periods, coexist in 
a singular and charming way and manifest Thessaloniki’s 
historical multicultural and cosmopolitan nature.

• Jewish history. (1st floor).

get organised in the city

', ' particularly the 
young – setting the pace of town life, the diversity of 
artistic events, the long list of choices for entertainment, 
the exceptional culinary tradition, and the fresh feel in 
the atmosphere, coming from the seafront, as well as the 
coolness of the northwest wind called Vardaris.   
Thessaloniki’s location is at the centre of a greater area 
with incomparable historical monuments and natural assets 
as it offers the opportunity for a visit to archaeological 
sites known the world over (Ancient Pella, Vergina, Dion, 
Petralona Cave), to areas of exquisite nature (river deltas, 
lakes, Mt Olympus), to the monastic state of Agion Oros 
[the Holy Mountain] as well as to Halkidiki, a famous tourist 
destination. And there is always an opportunity to practice 
sports (swimming, skiing, playing golf etc) or to indulge in 
wellness tourism (hot springs, spas)!
In short, Thessaloniki is a city that can cater for even the 
most demanding needs, any time of the year.

["<1-hop>

42 Thessaloniki’s Old Town is full of atmosphere. It covers the area in between the city walls (to the north and east) and Olympiados Street (to the south), and has had the luck to remain untouched by the 1917 great fire. It was virtually uninhabited until the mid-15th century, when it was conquered by the Ottomans who selected it for settlement on account of its fine climate, panoramic views and strategic position. The two and three-storey houses bear mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements (sachnisia) [Şahniş in turkish]; there are also residences with neoclassical and eclectic style motifs where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews. After 1922 many refugees settled in the area. Despite the construction of newer buildings and the opening up of new streets in recent decades, it has kept its original town planning, to a large extent, with narrow alleys and scant squares, as well as its original architectural features, particularly in the west and east part of the town. response:
## Historical Significance of the Roman Forum in Thessaloniki

The Roman Forum in Thessaloniki is a pivotal site that encapsulates the rich historical and cultural heritage of Macedonia. Established during the Roman period, it served as the social and religious center of the city, reflecting the architectural and urban planning of the time. The forum was constructed between the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD and played a crucial role in the daily life of Thessaloniki, showcasing the city's importance within the Roman Empire [Data: Sources (70), Entities (797)].

### Architectural and Cultural Hub

The Roman Forum is not just an archaeological site; it is a cultural hub that highlights the evolution of Thessaloniki through various historical epochs. The forum includes significant structures such as the Hellenistic Bathhouse and the Ancient Brothel, which provide insights into the social practices and daily life of the Hellenistic and Roman eras. These exhibits are essential for understanding the complexities of ancient Macedonian society, including social interactions and public health practices [Data: Reports (153), Entities (1438, 1439)].

### Connection to Macedonian Heritage

Thessaloniki, as the historic capital of Macedonia, has a deep connection to its Macedonian heritage, and the Roman Forum is a testament to this legacy. The forum's artifacts and architectural features reflect the region's historical significance, particularly during the Roman Empire when Macedonia was a vital province. The presence of artifacts from the Turkish Occupation further illustrates the forum's role in narrating the diverse historical influences that have shaped the region's identity [Data: Reports (153), Entities (1441)].

### Educational and Touristic Impact

The Roman Forum Museum, inaugurated in 2010, serves as a vital resource for educating visitors about the history and culture of Macedonia from the Hellenistic period to the 4th century AD. By showcasing various aspects of local history, the museum enhances the understanding of Macedonia's rich cultural heritage and promotes tourism in the area. This educational mission is crucial for fostering appreciation of the region's historical narrative and its relevance to contemporary discussions about cultural identity [Data: Reports (153), Entities (1438)].

In summary, the Roman Forum in Thessaloniki is a significant historical site that embodies the city's Macedonian heritage. Its architectural features, cultural artifacts, and educational initiatives contribute to a deeper understanding of the region's past and its ongoing influence on the present. The forum stands as a symbol of Thessaloniki's historical importance and its role in the broader context of Macedonian history [Data: Sources (70), Relationships (2, 313)].
reference: The Roman Forum in Thessaloniki, which served as the social and religious center of the city during the Roman period, highlights the city's Macedonian heritage. Constructed in two phases during the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD, it reflects the architectural and cultural influences of the time. The forum was gradually abandoned after the 7th century, but its remnants, including a large rectangular square and the double underground Cryptoporticus, provide insight into the historical significance of Thessaloniki as a key location in Macedonia.

Eptapyrgio was built in the 12th 
c., presumably on an older 9th c. 
fortress and took this name as 
at first there were seven towers 
there. The current structure 
includes ten towers and a small 
street that goes around it. The 
north side used to be a part  
of the city’s Early Christian 
walls, whereas the towers  
on the south side were added 
during the Byzantine period. In 
1431, the Ottoman Turks made 
certain modifications to them, 
according to an inscription 
placed above the entrance. 
Circa 1890 the construction 
was changed in order to house  
long-term convicts and newer 
buildings were added on 
the inside as well as on the 
outside area. In 1989, the 
prison, known by its Turkish 
name – Yedi Kule, was housed 
elsewhere and the fortress 
became a monument open to

At that time (4th – 15th c.), 
Christian monuments and

the town, and these make up

A tour across this unique 
open-air Byzantine museum  
is truly a special experience.
1 	\x07HOLY TWELVE  
APOSTLES CHURCH
One of the town’s oldest 
churches was built in 1310 – 
1314 under the sponsorship  
of Patriarch Nephon I. It used 
to be a katholicon [main church] 
of a monastery dedicated to 
Theotokos [Mother of God] as 
shown by the mural depicting 
Theotokos and the Founder, 
as well as by the iconography 
on the aisle with images of 
the Holy Virgin’s life. Out 
of the original monastery 
complex, -apart from the 
katholicon – there remain the

state buildings on this location 
(to create a civic centre);  
in 1966, however, excavations 
on the spot revealed the 
Ancient Roman Forum and  
the process was halted. In  
the centre of the square stands 
the imposing bust of Eleftherios 
Venizelos (1977, G. Pappas), 
who remained a prime minister 
of Greece for more than 12 
years during the period 1910 – 
1932. There are small copper 
workshops in the adjacent 
Chalkeon and Kleisouras 
Streets, and their business has 
been an ongoing tradition since 
the byzantine period.
1.4  Panagia [Virgin Mary] 
Chalkeon.
(see p. 9)
1.5  Bey Hamami.
It lies on the SE side of  
Plateia Dikastirion. This impressive 
edifice was built in 1444 and  
it is the country’s largest 
ottoman bath house, a multi-
domed construction with 
separate rooms for males and 
females, structured along two 
parallel ways. It is divided in 
three sections (cold, tepid 
and hot areas) and there is 
also a vaulted tank for heating 
water. It is widely known as the 
Paradise Baths and it went by 
that name until 1968. Right next 
to it there is a roman platform 
that is indicative of the ground 
level 2000 years ago.
1.6  Roman (Ancient) Forum
During the roman period, 
this 2-hectare area used to be 
the social and religious centre 
of the city. Construction was 
completed in two phases  
(in the mid-2nd and mid-  
3rd centuries AD) and it was 
gradually abandoned after the 
7th century. The NW section 
of', '

HISTORIC CENTRE (3)
that the place had been used 
by Christians as well, during 
the late Roman period. South 
of the passageway there 
were shops dating from the 
1st until the 13th century; the 
underground Museum of the 
Roman Forum (see p. 71) was 
built there as an extension. 
A 2nd - 4th c. AD Odeon [C] 
was found behind the well-
preserved eastern stoa. It  
has been restored and it is now 
used as a venue for cultural 
events. A mint and an archive 
office are right next to it. In the 
SE side, a round bath house 
[D] was unearthed which has 
been in use since the 1st c. BC. 
Parts of a colonnade, mosaic 
floors, marble stairs, a section 
of a stone-paved street, sewer 
pipes, silver coins, stone and 
marble sculptures were all 
found in this archaeological 
site. The forum is also where 
the “Enchanted Ones” (las 
Incantadas) were discovered, 
a two-storeyed colonnaded 
archway with Corinthian-order 
columns and pillars four of 
which have survived. They are 
decorated with figures in relief 
in their interior as well as their 
exterior side (“Stoa of the 
Statuettes”). It is estimated 
that the Stoa’s location was 
at the south entrance to the 
forum (from Egnatia Street);  
in 1864 the pillars were 
removed and escorted to their 
present location at the Louvre 
Museum (Paris) by E. Miller.

atmosphere, Bit Pazar (meaning 
Small Market place) is a spot

11	\x07BYZANTINE BATHS  
(KULE KAFE)
It is located on Romfei Sq. (see 
p. 43) in Ano Poli and it is the 
only surviving Byzantine bath 
house, a domed 13th c. building 
made of brick, which was 
open to the public until 1940.

UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
During the Ottoman period it 
was named Kule Hamam and 
was divided in two (male and 
female section).
12 	\x07HOSIOS DAVID  
(MONI LATOMOU)
Moni Latomou [Latomou 
Monastery] has a huge 
archaeological and historical 
value, since it is an early type 
of a cross-in-square domed 
church. Its construction dates 
back to the 5th or 6th c. and 
it is believed to have been 
built by Theodora, daughter 
of the Byzantine emperor 
Maximilianus, who had been 
baptised a Christian. The 
monastery was dedicated to 
Hosios David [Saint David] in 
1921. Especially noteworthy 
are the mosaic depictions 
on the ceiling which show 
the Vision of Ezekiel and 
are contemporary to the 
construction of the monastery; 
the later ones of the 12th, 13th 
and 14th c. are also great art 
specimens of the Komnenian 
period. There is a surviving 
minaret entrance built in the 
16th c. when the church was 
converted into a mosque. The', 'thex. 
In 1430 it was converted into 
a mosque and was named 
Kazancilar Camii.
3 	\x07
ACHEIROPOIITOS 
CHURCH
It was founded in the second 
half of the 5th c. on the site 
of the roman public baths 
and it was dedicated to 
Panagia (Virgin Mary). It is a 
three-aisled, timber-roofed 
basilica with a narthex and a 
gallery. The nave is separated 
by the side aisles with 
colonnades of Theodosian-
style pillars and impost 
capitals made of marble 
as is made the floor of the 
nave. The preserved mosaic 
decorations date to the 5th 
c. whereas the murals on the 
south aisle date to the 13th 
c. After the city was captured 
by the Turks, this was the 
first church to be turned into 
a mosque. In 1922-1923 it 
housed refugees from Asia 
Minor and in 1939 Christian 
worship was once again 
practiced in it.
4 	\x07
AGIA SOFIA CHURCH 
[or ΗAGIA SOPHIA]
It was built in the mid-7th c.  
on the ruins of a 5th c. basilica, 
as a copy of Hagia Sophia 
[Holy Wisdom of God] in 
Constantinople, and is one  
of the most important early-
3
2

1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
Christian monuments in the 
Orthodox world. It is a cross-
domed basilica and used to 
be the Metropolitan Church 
(Cathedral) until 1523 when it 
was converted into a mosque; 
it was restored to Christian 
worship after 1912.', ' [ROTONTA]
This impressive round building 
lies on the route connecting 
the triumphal arch of Galerius 
(Kamara, see p. 37) and the 
Palace of Galerius (see p. 29). 
It has a diameter of 24.5 m. 
and its gigantic dome is 30 
m. high. It was built in 306 
AD by Galerius, probably as a 
temple of Zeus or Kaveiros or 
as a mausoleum; in the 5th c. 
it was converted into a church 
dedicated to the Holy Bodiless 
Powers. The 5th c. outstanding 
preserved mosaics impress 
with their variety of themes, 
their naturalistic rendering, 
the colour diversity and the 
brilliance of the gold and 
silver tesserae. In 1591 it was 
turned into a mosque when a 
towering minaret was added, 
which survives today. In the 
square, next to Rotunda, lies 
the small church of Agios  
Georgios [St. George] whence 
the monument took its
