7th walk: 
WEST OF THE CENTRE-STAVROUPOLI
inaugurated in 1962 (S. Molfesis, 
Th. Papagiannis). Its exterior 
side combines modern and 
classical elements with wings 
added on the sides. It connects 
Thessaloniki with the rest of 
Greece, the Balkans and Istanbul; 
it is also the bus terminus 
towards most of the city areas. 
This will be the location of the 
west metro line terminus under 
construction in Thessaloniki.
2.2  Old Railway Station.
It was built in 1894 near the 
harbour (Old Station Street) 
in the neoclassical style, 
and it gradually connected 
Thessaloniki with Skopje, 
Belgrade, Monastir and 
Constantinople (modern-day 
Istanbul). Today it', ' the year it was 
founded until the present day, 
the history of Thessaloniki is 
depicted through an array of 
multimedia applications, special 
structures, printed graphic 
design compositions and 
archaeological material. The 
exhibition is organised in seven 
thematic categories, each one 
occupying one floor, as follows: 
Space and Time (ground floor), 
Transformations (1st floor), 
Monuments and History (2nd 
floor), Homeland of the people 
(3rd floor), Along the trade 
routes (4th floor), Leisure and 
Culture (5th floor), Thessaloniki 
– Flavours (6th floor). The 
museum’s shop is located on 
the last floor.
JEWISH MUSEUM OF 
THESSALONIKI
It was created following 
an initiative of the Jewish 
Community of Thessaloniki  
to promote the Sephardic 
legacy in town, which dates  
as far back as the 15th c. It has 
been open to visitors since 
1997. It houses a Centre of 
Research and Study of the 
Jewish History in Thessaloniki, 
an extensive library and an 
Audiovisual Centre. Permanent 
exhibitions are divided in four 
categories, as follows:
• Jewish necropolis. 
(ground floor). Tombstones and 
stelae with epitaph inscriptions 
are on display, from the great 
Jewish necropolis which 
used to lie east of the city 
walls. Photographs show the 
cemetery as it was in 1914.
• Jewish history. (1st floor). 
It occupies the central area 
with a narrative of the Jewish 
presence in Thessaloniki up  
to World War II.
• Folk Art and Life. (1st 
floor). A large array of exhibits 
paints a vivid picture of the

was a large court surrounded

and workshops, as well as

Temples. Excavations

The earlier buildings date to

were added later. In the 
centre there was a peristyle 
surrounding the courtyard, 
a propylaeum, and the royal 
quarters were on the north side.
Eastern cemetery. It is 
located east of the town.

Archaeοlogical Museum. 
This modern museum is 
among the most interesting 
ones in Northern Greece. 
Exhibits are grouped in 5 
principal thematic categories: 
in the first one, exhibits  
relate to the daily life of  
the Pella residents (mosaics, 
wall decorations, objects  
of everyday use and so on);  
in the second one, the public 
life is depicted with finds 
mostly from the Agora area;  
in the third one, objects used 
in the temples are on display 
and information is given on  
the local religious practices;  
in the fourth one, there are 
finds from the cemeteries and 
in the fifth one, focus is placed 
on the architectural design and 
structuring of the palace, as 
well as on the life of Alexander 
the Great. An interesting film

1.1  Military Museum  
of the Balkan Wars.
It is located in Gefyra village, 
25km NW of Thessaloniki, and 
it is housed in the mansion 
of J. Modiano (1906, P. 
Arrigoni). This is where the 
Greek army headquarters were 
set up by Constantine, the 
then heir to the Greek throne, 
on October 24-27, 1912; 
the final negotiations with 
the Turks about surrendering 
Thessaloniki took place on that 
spot. Rare relics are on display 
such as maps, uniforms, arms, 
medals, documents, items of 
daily use, and so on,']

UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS Thessaloniki has been one of the first towns to know the Christian religion by the Apostle Paul; during the Byzantine period it used to be the second most important city of the empire (co-reigning city) after Constantinople. At that time (4th – 15th c.), Christian monuments and churches were constructed in the town, and these make up a diachronic typology with a decisive influence on the entire Byzantine world. The following early-Christian and Byzantine monuments of the town are considered to be excellent specimens of the Byzantine church-building and art, and for this reason UNESCO declared them to be World Heritage Monuments, in 1988. A tour across this unique open-air Byzantine museum is truly a special experience. 1 \x07HOLY TWELVE APOSTLES CHURCH One of the town’s oldest churches was built in 1310 – 1314 under the sponsorship of Patriarch Nephon I. It used to be a katholicon [main church] of a monastery dedicated to Theotokos [Mother of God] as shown by the mural depicting Theotokos and the Founder, as well as by the iconography on the aisle with images of the Holy Virgin’s life. Roman (Ancient) Forum During the roman period, this 2-hectare area used to be the social and religious centre of the city. Construction was completed in two phases (in the mid-2nd and mid- 3rd centuries AD) and it was gradually abandoned after the 7th century. The NW section of the archaeological site is covered by a large rectangular square [Α] with traces of marble paving. In the S section of the square lies the largest part of the double underground Cryptoporticus [covered passageway] [Β] which was most probably used as a public storehouse. response:
## Significance of the Early Christian Mural in the Roman Forum

The early Christian mural found in the Roman Forum is a significant artifact that reflects the religious and cultural transitions that occurred in Thessaloniki during the late Roman period. This mural, along with other remnants from the early Christian era, showcases the architectural and artistic influences of Christianity as it began to establish itself in the region. The Roman Forum itself served as a central hub for social and religious activities, making the presence of such a mural particularly meaningful as it indicates the integration of Christian themes into public life during a time when Christianity was gaining prominence.

The mural is part of a broader narrative that includes various early Christian monuments in Thessaloniki, which collectively highlight the city's rich religious heritage. These monuments, such as the Agia Sofia Church and other Byzantine structures, are recognized for their historical and architectural significance, contributing to Thessaloniki's designation as a UNESCO World Heritage site. The early Christian mural thus serves as a visual representation of the transition from paganism to Christianity, marking a pivotal moment in the city's history [Data: Reports (316); Entities (1010, 71, 424); Relationships (2396, 2397)].

## Relationship to Christian Monuments in Thessaloniki

The early Christian mural is intrinsically linked to the broader category of Christian monuments in Thessaloniki, which are essential for understanding the city's religious evolution. These monuments, built during the Byzantine period, reflect the artistic and architectural achievements of the time, showcasing the influence of Christian doctrine on the cultural landscape. The presence of the mural in the Roman Forum indicates that even in public spaces, Christian themes were becoming increasingly prominent, suggesting a shift in societal values and beliefs.

Moreover, the early Christian walls and other structures in Thessaloniki serve as a testament to the city's historical significance as a center of early Christianity. The interconnectedness of these sites, including the Roman Forum, emphasizes the importance of Thessaloniki in the context of Christian history and its role in the Byzantine Empire. The mural, therefore, not only enriches the narrative of the Roman Forum but also enhances the understanding of the city's identity as a historical and cultural crossroads for early Christian art and architecture [Data: Entities (71, 424); Relationships (2396, 2397)].

In summary, the early Christian mural in the Roman Forum is a vital piece of Thessaloniki's historical tapestry, illustrating the city's transition to Christianity and its significance as a center for early Christian monuments. This relationship underscores the importance of Thessaloniki in the broader context of Christian heritage and its lasting impact on the region's cultural identity.
reference: The early Christian mural found in the Roman Forum is significant as it represents the transition of the city into a center of Christian faith during the late Roman period. This mural, uncovered in a public storehouse, showcases the artistic expression of early Christianity. It relates to the Christian monuments in Thessaloniki, which were constructed during the Byzantine period and reflect the city's historical importance as one of the first towns to embrace Christianity, influenced by the Apostle Paul. Both the mural and the monuments highlight Thessaloniki's rich Christian heritage and its role in the broader Byzantine world.

namely Mytikas and Stefani.
3.2  Ancient Pydna.
It lies 43 km N of Dion and 
it was built in the 8th – 7th c. 
BC. During the 4th c. BC the 
Macedon king Philip II made 
Pydna the administrative 
centre of the district. In 168 
BC, Roman troops defeated 
the Macedonian army near 
the town, and that meant 
the beginning of Roman rule 
in Macedonia. Gradually the 
town went into decline and 
was successively occupied by 
Bulgarians, western Europeans 
and Turks, and got eventually 
deserted in the 15th c. 
Excavations have unearthed 
109

92
DAY EXCURSIONS
a neolithic settlement which 
is considered to have been 
the largest in the Hellenic 
area, a cemetery, two early-
Christian basilicas (4th and 
6th c.) and a 10th c. basilica 
with remarkable mosaics and 
murals.
How to get there.  
Dion is situated 87 km SW 
of Thessaloniki. Follow the 
national road to Athens and 
then the signs to Katerini and 
Dion. Alternatively, take the 
coach to Katerini (Pieria district) 
and then the local bus to Dion.
4 	PETRALONA CAVE
It was discovered in 1959, 
by accident, in the western 
part of Halkidiki. It is 1,500 
m. long (a 400 m. section is 
open to visitors); the chambers, 
the stalagtite and stalagmite 
formations within are very 
interesting. The location 
became universally known 
when an array of prehistoric 
items was found in the interior 
(fossil tree leaves,', 'ZANTINE MONUMENTS
14	\x07AGIOS NIKOLAOS 
[SAINT NICHOLAS] 
ORPHANOS CHURCH
It was built in the 1310s,  
as a dependency of Vlatadon 
Monastery and it served as a 
monastery main church. Within 
the same grounds there used 
to be an orphanage at earlier 
times – hence the name 
“Orphanos” [meaning Orphan]. 
It is an aisleless timber-roofed 
church sided by an ambulatory 
forming the shape “Π”.  
The 14th c. murals inside are 
true masterpieces depicting 
scenes of Dodekaorto [the 
Twelve major religious feasts  
of the year], of the Passion  
of Christ, the Resurrection and 
the Liturgical Cycle as well as 
figures of saints; the monument 
is considered as one of the 
best preserved in Thessaloniki. 
It is surrounded by lush and 
serene gardens.
15	CITY WALLS
Thessaloniki was walled 
immediately after it was 
founded by Cassander; in 
390 AD a series of large-
scale changes took place by 
Theodosius I. In the Byzantine 
times a harbour was constructed 
(in the SW part) and the 
Acropolis wall was raised (see 
p. 44). During the Venetian Rule 
(1st half of the 15th c.) there 
were efforts to boost it in the 
light of the Turkish threat; this 
is why certain scholars support 
that the Trigoniou Tower (see p. 
45) and the White Tower (see p. 
24) were built during that period. 
In the following centuries, the 
Turks completed reinforcement 
works in various places. The 
wall inscriptions describe the 
interventions and restorations', 'th 
and 14th c. are also great art 
specimens of the Komnenian 
period. There is a surviving 
minaret entrance built in the 
16th c. when the church was 
converted into a mosque. The 
small picturesque yard offers 
an unobstructed view of the 
city and the Thermaic gulf.
13 	MONI VLATADON
It is the only Byzantine 
monastery in the city with 
an active community. It was 
founded in the 14th c. by the 
monks Vlatis (or Vlateus) 
brothers and was dedicated to 
Pantocrator Christos [Almighty 
Christ]. Celebrations take 
place on the Transfiguration 
of Christ feast day. Its main 
church [katholikon] is of the 
inscribed cross-in-square type 
but the dome rests on the 
walls and on two piers instead 
of columns. It is surrounded 
by a portico and there are two 
chapels. Murals were painted 
during 1360 – 1380 and the 
17th c. iconostasis is particularly 
noteworthy. It is surrounded 
by a large garden offering a 
wonderful view of the city and 
there is also a small peacock 
farm; in the grounds you will 
also find the newer buildings 
of Misirogleios Library, the 
Patriarchal Foundation for 
Theological Studies (1968),  
a space provided for the study of 
pictorial manuscripts from Mount 
Athos, a bookstore and a shop.

UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS Thessaloniki has been one of the first towns to know the Christian religion by the Apostle Paul; during the Byzantine period it used to be the second most important city of the empire (co-reigning city) after Constantinople. At that time (4th – 15th c.), Christian monuments and churches were constructed in the town, and these make up a diachronic typology with a decisive influence on the entire Byzantine world. The following early-Christian and Byzantine monuments of the town are considered to be excellent specimens of the Byzantine church-building and art, and for this reason UNESCO declared them to be World Heritage Monuments, in 1988. response:
### Significant Christian Murals in Thessaloniki

Thessaloniki, a city rich in Christian heritage, is home to numerous significant murals that reflect its historical and religious importance. Among these, the murals found in the **Holy Twelve Apostles Church** and those associated with the **Roman Forum** stand out for their artistic and theological significance.

#### Holy Twelve Apostles Church

The **Holy Twelve Apostles Church**, built between 1310 and 1314, is one of the oldest churches in Thessaloniki and showcases remarkable Byzantine art. The church was originally the main church of a monastery dedicated to Theotokos (Mother of God) and features exquisite murals that depict various religious scenes. Notably, the murals illustrate the life of the Virgin Mary and significant events in Christian theology, including the **Ascension of Christ** and the **Passion of Christ**. These artworks not only serve a religious purpose but also highlight the artistic skills of the period, making the church a vital cultural landmark in Thessaloniki [Data: Entities (67, 439); Reports (1)].

The murals within the Holy Twelve Apostles Church are recognized for their intricate details and vibrant colors, which contribute to the overall aesthetic and spiritual experience of the site. The church's artistic heritage is a testament to the Byzantine influence on Christian iconography, attracting both worshippers and art historians alike [Data: Entities (67, 439); Relationships (20)].

#### Roman Forum Murals

While the Roman Forum itself is primarily known for its archaeological significance, it also features remnants of early Christian art that reflect the transition from paganism to Christianity in the region. The forum was a central hub in ancient Thessaloniki, and as Christianity spread, many of its structures were repurposed for Christian worship. Murals from this period often depict scenes from the life of Christ and various saints, illustrating the early Christian community's beliefs and practices [Data: Sources (1)].

The murals found in the Roman Forum are significant as they represent the early integration of Christian themes into public life and architecture, marking a pivotal moment in Thessaloniki's religious history. These artworks serve as a bridge between the city's ancient past and its Christian present, showcasing the evolution of artistic expression in the context of changing religious landscapes [Data: Sources (1)].

### Conclusion

In summary, the murals in Thessaloniki, particularly those in the Holy Twelve Apostles Church and the Roman Forum, are vital components of the city's rich Christian heritage. They not only reflect the artistic achievements of the Byzantine era but also serve as important historical markers of the transition to Christianity in the region. These sites continue to attract visitors interested in both their spiritual significance and their artistic value, making Thessaloniki a key destination for those exploring early Christian art and architecture [Data: Entities (67, 439); Reports (1)].
reference: In Thessaloniki, the Holy Twelve Apostles Church, built between 1310 and 1314, features a mural depicting Theotokos (Mother of God) and the Founder, showcasing early Christian iconography. Additionally, the Roman Forum, which served as the social and religious center during the Roman period, contains a valuable early Christian mural uncovered in its underground Cryptoporticus, further highlighting the city's rich Christian heritage.

1 	\x07HOLY TWELVE  
APOSTLES CHURCH
One of the town’s oldest 
churches was built in 1310 – 
1314 under the sponsorship  
of Patriarch Nephon I. It used 
to be a katholicon [main church] 
of a monastery dedicated to 
Theotokos [Mother of God] as 
shown by the mural depicting 
Theotokos and the Founder, 
as well as by the iconography 
on the aisle with images of 
the Holy Virgin’s life. Out 
of the original monastery 
complex, -apart from the 
katholicon – there remain the

state buildings on this location 
(to create a civic centre);  
in 1966, however, excavations 
on the spot revealed the 
Ancient Roman Forum and  
the process was halted. In  
the centre of the square stands 
the imposing bust of Eleftherios 
Venizelos (1977, G. Pappas), 
who remained a prime minister 
of Greece for more than 12 
years during the period 1910 – 
1932. There are small copper 
workshops in the adjacent 
Chalkeon and Kleisouras 
Streets, and their business has 
been an ongoing tradition since 
the byzantine period.
1.4  Panagia [Virgin Mary] 
Chalkeon.
(see p. 9)
1.5  Bey Hamami.
It lies on the SE side of  
Plateia Dikastirion. This impressive 
edifice was built in 1444 and  
it is the country’s largest 
ottoman bath house, a multi-
domed construction with 
separate rooms for males and 
females, structured along two 
parallel ways. It is divided in 
three sections (cold, tepid 
and hot areas) and there is 
also a vaulted tank for heating 
water. It is widely known as the 
Paradise Baths and it went by 
that name until 1968. Right next 
to it there is a roman platform 
that is indicative of the ground 
level 2000 years ago.
1.6  Roman (Ancient) Forum
During the roman period, 
this 2-hectare area used to be 
the social and religious centre 
of the city. Construction was 
completed in two phases  
(in the mid-2nd and mid-  
3rd centuries AD) and it was 
gradually abandoned after the 
7th century. The NW section 
of', '

HISTORIC CENTRE (3)
that the place had been used 
by Christians as well, during 
the late Roman period. South 
of the passageway there 
were shops dating from the 
1st until the 13th century; the 
underground Museum of the 
Roman Forum (see p. 71) was 
built there as an extension. 
A 2nd - 4th c. AD Odeon [C] 
was found behind the well-
preserved eastern stoa. It  
has been restored and it is now 
used as a venue for cultural 
events. A mint and an archive 
office are right next to it. In the 
SE side, a round bath house 
[D] was unearthed which has 
been in use since the 1st c. BC. 
Parts of a colonnade, mosaic 
floors, marble stairs, a section 
of a stone-paved street, sewer 
pipes, silver coins, stone and 
marble sculptures were all 
found in this archaeological 
site. The forum is also where 
the “Enchanted Ones” (las 
Incantadas) were discovered, 
a two-storeyed colonnaded 
archway with Corinthian-order 
columns and pillars four of 
which have survived. They are 
decorated with figures in relief 
in their interior as well as their 
exterior side (“Stoa of the 
Statuettes”). It is estimated 
that the Stoa’s location was 
at the south entrance to the 
forum (from Egnatia Street);  
in 1864 the pillars were 
removed and escorted to their 
present location at the Louvre 
Museum (Paris) by E. Miller.

atmosphere, Bit Pazar (meaning 
Small Market place) is a spot

11	\x07BYZANTINE BATHS  
(KULE KAFE)
It is located on Romfei Sq. (see 
p. 43) in Ano Poli and it is the 
only surviving Byzantine bath 
house, a domed 13th c. building 
made of brick, which was 
open to the public until 1940.

UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
During the Ottoman period it 
was named Kule Hamam and 
was divided in two (male and 
female section).
12 	\x07HOSIOS DAVID  
(MONI LATOMOU)
Moni Latomou [Latomou 
Monastery] has a huge 
archaeological and historical 
value, since it is an early type 
of a cross-in-square domed 
church. Its construction dates 
back to the 5th or 6th c. and 
it is believed to have been 
built by Theodora, daughter 
of the Byzantine emperor 
Maximilianus, who had been 
baptised a Christian. The 
monastery was dedicated to 
Hosios David [Saint David] in 
1921. Especially noteworthy 
are the mosaic depictions 
on the ceiling which show 
the Vision of Ezekiel and 
are contemporary to the 
construction of the monastery; 
the later ones of the 12th, 13th 
and 14th c. are also great art 
specimens of the Komnenian 
period. There is a surviving 
minaret entrance built in the 
16th c. when the church was 
converted into a mosque. The', 'thex. 
In 1430 it was converted into 
a mosque and was named 
Kazancilar Camii.
3 	\x07
ACHEIROPOIITOS 
CHURCH
It was founded in the second 
half of the 5th c. on the site 
of the roman public baths 
and it was dedicated to 
Panagia (Virgin Mary). It is a 
three-aisled, timber-roofed 
basilica with a narthex and a 
gallery. The nave is separated 
by the side aisles with 
colonnades of Theodosian-
style pillars and impost 
capitals made of marble 
as is made the floor of the 
nave. The preserved mosaic 
decorations date to the 5th 
c. whereas the murals on the 
south aisle date to the 13th 
c. After the city was captured 
by the Turks, this was the 
first church to be turned into 
a mosque. In 1922-1923 it 
housed refugees from Asia 
Minor and in 1939 Christian 
worship was once again 
practiced in it.
4 	\x07
AGIA SOFIA CHURCH 
[or ΗAGIA SOPHIA]
It was built in the mid-7th c.  
on the ruins of a 5th c. basilica, 
as a copy of Hagia Sophia 
[Holy Wisdom of God] in 
Constantinople, and is one  
of the most important early-
3
2

1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
Christian monuments in the 
Orthodox world. It is a cross-
domed basilica and used to 
be the Metropolitan Church 
(Cathedral) until 1523 when it 
was converted into a mosque; 
it was restored to Christian 
worship after 1912.', ' [ROTONTA]
This impressive round building 
lies on the route connecting 
the triumphal arch of Galerius 
(Kamara, see p. 37) and the 
Palace of Galerius (see p. 29). 
It has a diameter of 24.5 m. 
and its gigantic dome is 30 
m. high. It was built in 306 
AD by Galerius, probably as a 
temple of Zeus or Kaveiros or 
as a mausoleum; in the 5th c. 
it was converted into a church 
dedicated to the Holy Bodiless 
Powers. The 5th c. outstanding 
preserved mosaics impress 
with their variety of themes, 
their naturalistic rendering, 
the colour diversity and the 
brilliance of the gold and 
silver tesserae. In 1591 it was 
turned into a mosque when a 
towering minaret was added, 
which survives today. In the 
square, next to Rotunda, lies 
the small church of Agios  
Georgios [St. George] whence 
the monument took its

7th walk: 
WEST OF THE CENTRE-STAVROUPOLI
inaugurated in 1962 (S. Molfesis, 
Th. Papagiannis). Its exterior 
side combines modern and 
classical elements with wings 
added on the sides. It connects 
Thessaloniki with the rest of 
Greece, the Balkans and Istanbul; 
it is also the bus terminus 
towards most of the city areas. 
This will be the location of the 
west metro line terminus under 
construction in Thessaloniki.
2.2  Old Railway Station.
It was built in 1894 near the 
harbour (Old Station Street) 
in the neoclassical style, 
and it gradually connected 
Thessaloniki with Skopje, 
Belgrade, Monastir and 
Constantinople (modern-day 
Istanbul). Today it', ' the year it was 
founded until the present day, 
the history of Thessaloniki is 
depicted through an array of 
multimedia applications, special 
structures, printed graphic 
design compositions and 
archaeological material. The 
exhibition is organised in seven 
thematic categories, each one 
occupying one floor, as follows: 
Space and Time (ground floor), 
Transformations (1st floor), 
Monuments and History (2nd 
floor), Homeland of the people 
(3rd floor), Along the trade 
routes (4th floor), Leisure and 
Culture (5th floor), Thessaloniki 
– Flavours (6th floor). The 
museum’s shop is located on 
the last floor.
JEWISH MUSEUM OF 
THESSALONIKI
It was created following 
an initiative of the Jewish 
Community of Thessaloniki  
to promote the Sephardic 
legacy in town, which dates  
as far back as the 15th c. It has 
been open to visitors since 
1997. It houses a Centre of 
Research and Study of the 
Jewish History in Thessaloniki, 
an extensive library and an 
Audiovisual Centre. Permanent 
exhibitions are divided in four 
categories, as follows:
• Jewish necropolis. 
(ground floor). Tombstones and 
stelae with epitaph inscriptions 
are on display, from the great 
Jewish necropolis which 
used to lie east of the city 
walls. Photographs show the 
cemetery as it was in 1914.
• Jewish history. (1st floor). 
It occupies the central area 
with a narrative of the Jewish 
presence in Thessaloniki up  
to World War II.
• Folk Art and Life. (1st 
floor). A large array of exhibits 
paints a vivid picture of the

was a large court surrounded

and workshops, as well as

Temples. Excavations

The earlier buildings date to

were added later. In the 
centre there was a peristyle 
surrounding the courtyard, 
a propylaeum, and the royal 
quarters were on the north side.
Eastern cemetery. It is 
located east of the town.

Archaeοlogical Museum. 
This modern museum is 
among the most interesting 
ones in Northern Greece. 
Exhibits are grouped in 5 
principal thematic categories: 
in the first one, exhibits  
relate to the daily life of  
the Pella residents (mosaics, 
wall decorations, objects  
of everyday use and so on);  
in the second one, the public 
life is depicted with finds 
mostly from the Agora area;  
in the third one, objects used 
in the temples are on display 
and information is given on  
the local religious practices;  
in the fourth one, there are 
finds from the cemeteries and 
in the fifth one, focus is placed 
on the architectural design and 
structuring of the palace, as 
well as on the life of Alexander 
the Great. An interesting film

1.1  Military Museum  
of the Balkan Wars.
It is located in Gefyra village, 
25km NW of Thessaloniki, and 
it is housed in the mansion 
of J. Modiano (1906, P. 
Arrigoni). This is where the 
Greek army headquarters were 
set up by Constantine, the 
then heir to the Greek throne, 
on October 24-27, 1912; 
the final negotiations with 
the Turks about surrendering 
Thessaloniki took place on that 
spot. Rare relics are on display 
such as maps, uniforms, arms, 
medals, documents, items of 
daily use, and so on,']

UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS Thessaloniki has been one of the first towns to know the Christian religion by the Apostle Paul; during the Byzantine period it used to be the second most important city of the empire (co-reigning city) after Constantinople. At that time (4th – 15th c.), Christian monuments and churches were constructed in the town, and these make up a diachronic typology with a decisive influence on the entire Byzantine world. The following early-Christian and Byzantine monuments of the town are considered to be excellent specimens of the Byzantine church-building and art, and for this reason UNESCO declared them to be World Heritage Monuments, in 1988. A tour across this unique open-air Byzantine museum is truly a special experience. 1 \x07HOLY TWELVE APOSTLES CHURCH One of the town’s oldest churches was built in 1310 – 1314 under the sponsorship of Patriarch Nephon I. It used to be a katholicon [main church] of a monastery dedicated to Theotokos [Mother of God] as shown by the mural depicting Theotokos and the Founder, as well as by the iconography on the aisle with images of the Holy Virgin’s life. Roman (Ancient) Forum During the roman period, this 2-hectare area used to be the social and religious centre of the city. The NW section of the archaeological site is covered by a large rectangular square [Α] with traces of marble paving. response:
## Significance of the Early Christian Mural in the Roman Forum

The early Christian mural found in the Roman Forum is a significant artifact that reflects the religious and cultural transitions that occurred in Thessaloniki during the late Roman period. This mural, which dates back to the 4th century AD, is part of the broader context of early Christian architecture and art that emerged as Christianity began to establish itself in the region. The mural serves as a visual representation of the early Christian community's beliefs and practices, showcasing the artistic styles and themes prevalent during that time.

The Roman Forum itself was a central hub for social and religious activities in Thessaloniki, functioning as the city's administrative and cultural heart. The presence of early Christian murals within this historically rich site indicates the integration of Christian themes into the public and civic life of the city, marking a significant shift from pagan traditions to Christian practices. This transition is further emphasized by the fact that the Roman Forum was previously a site of pagan worship and civic gatherings, making the mural a poignant symbol of the changing religious landscape in Thessaloniki [Data: Reports (316); Entities (797); Relationships (2397)].

## Relationship to Christian Monuments in Thessaloniki

The early Christian mural is intrinsically linked to the broader category of Christian monuments in Thessaloniki, which includes various structures built during the Byzantine period. These monuments, such as the Agia Sofia Church and other early Christian basilicas, reflect the city's rich religious heritage and its significance as a center of early Christianity in the Byzantine Empire. The murals and architectural styles found in these monuments often share thematic and stylistic elements, showcasing the continuity of artistic expression and religious devotion from the early Christian period through the Byzantine era [Data: Entities (71); Relationships (2396)].

Moreover, the early Christian mural contributes to the UNESCO designation of several monuments in Thessaloniki, which are recognized for their historical and architectural significance. This designation highlights the importance of preserving these sites as part of the world's cultural heritage, emphasizing their role in understanding the evolution of Christian art and architecture in the region [Data: Entities (424); Relationships (1300)].

In summary, the early Christian mural in the Roman Forum is not only a significant artistic work but also a vital piece of Thessaloniki's historical narrative. It illustrates the transition to Christianity in the city and connects to the broader network of Christian monuments that define Thessaloniki's cultural and religious identity. The mural serves as a testament to the city's rich heritage and its role as a pivotal center for early Christian art and architecture in the Byzantine world.
reference: The early Christian mural found in the Roman Forum is significant as it represents the social and religious center of the city during the Roman period, showcasing the transition to Christianity in the region. This mural, uncovered on one of the walls of the Cryptoporticus, highlights the influence of Christian art and architecture that developed in Thessaloniki, which was one of the first towns to embrace Christianity through the Apostle Paul. The Christian monuments in Thessaloniki, including churches built during the Byzantine period, reflect this rich heritage and the city's role as a major center for early Christian culture.

It lies 43 km N of Dion and 
it was built in the 8th – 7th c. 
BC. During the 4th c. BC the 
Macedon king Philip II made 
Pydna the administrative 
centre of the district. In 168 
BC, Roman troops defeated 
the Macedonian army near 
the town, and that meant 
the beginning of Roman rule 
in Macedonia. Gradually the 
town went into decline and 
was successively occupied by 
Bulgarians, western Europeans 
and Turks, and got eventually 
deserted in the 15th c.

UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS Thessaloniki has been one of the first towns to know the Christian religion by the Apostle Paul; during the Byzantine period it used to be the second most important city of the empire (co-reigning city) after Constantinople. At that time (4th – 15th c.), Christian monuments and churches were constructed in the town, and these make up a diachronic typology with a decisive influence on the entire Byzantine world. The following early-Christian and Byzantine monuments of the town are considered to be excellent specimens of the Byzantine church-building and art, and for this reason UNESCO declared them to be World Heritage Monuments, in 1988. A tour across this unique open-air Byzantine museum is truly a special experience. 1 \x07HOLY TWELVE APOSTLES CHURCH One of the town’s oldest churches was built in 1310 – 1314 under the sponsorship of Patriarch Nephon I. It used to be a katholicon [main church] of a monastery dedicated to Theotokos [Mother of God] as shown by the mural depicting Theotokos and the Founder, as well as by the iconography on the aisle with images of the Holy Virgin’s life. response:
## Significance of Christian Murals in Thessaloniki's Byzantine Monuments

Christian murals are a vital aspect of Thessaloniki's Byzantine heritage, serving not only as artistic expressions but also as reflections of the religious and cultural practices of the time. In the context of the Holy Twelve Apostles Church and the Roman Forum, these murals hold particular significance, showcasing the intricate relationship between art, faith, and community identity.

### The Holy Twelve Apostles Church

The Holy Twelve Apostles Church, built between 1310 and 1314, is one of the oldest churches in Thessaloniki and is recognized for its historical and architectural importance. The church features remarkable murals that depict various religious scenes, including the life of the Virgin Mary, which are integral to its artistic and spiritual significance. These murals, crafted in different stages from the 8th to the 11th centuries, highlight the evolution of Byzantine art and its role in enhancing the worship experience within the church [Data: Reports (160); Entities (67, 1280)].

The murals in the Holy Twelve Apostles Church not only serve as decorative elements but also as didactic tools, conveying biblical narratives and theological concepts to the congregation. This function is particularly important in a historical context where literacy rates were low, making visual storytelling a crucial means of religious education. The church's murals thus contribute to the preservation of Christian teachings and the cultural identity of the community [Data: Relationships (65, 2395)].

### The Roman Forum

The Roman Forum, a significant archaeological site in Thessaloniki, also features remnants of early Christian murals that reflect the city's transition from a pagan to a Christian society. These murals, found in the context of the forum's early Christian basilica, illustrate the integration of Christian iconography into public spaces, signifying the growing prominence of Christianity in the region during the Byzantine era. The presence of such murals in a civic space underscores the importance of faith in everyday life and the communal aspect of worship [Data: Entities (1010); Relationships (1869)].

The murals in the Roman Forum serve as a testament to the artistic achievements of the Byzantine period, showcasing the intricate craftsmanship and theological themes that characterized the era. They provide insight into the socio-religious dynamics of Thessaloniki, illustrating how art was employed to communicate and reinforce Christian values within the public sphere [Data: Relationships (1869)].

### Conclusion

In summary, Christian murals in Thessaloniki's Byzantine monuments, particularly in the Holy Twelve Apostles Church and the Roman Forum, hold profound significance. They are not merely artistic decorations but serve as vital links to the city's religious heritage, reflecting the theological, cultural, and social narratives of the Byzantine era. The preservation and appreciation of these murals are essential for understanding the historical context of Thessaloniki and the enduring legacy of its Christian heritage [Data: Reports (160); Entities (67, 1280, 1010)].
reference: Christian murals in Thessaloniki's Byzantine monuments are significant as they reflect the city's early adoption of Christianity and its rich religious heritage. The Holy Twelve Apostles Church, built between 1310 and 1314, features a mural depicting Theotokos, showcasing the church's dedication to the Mother of God and its role in the Byzantine religious landscape. Additionally, the Roman Forum, which served as a social and religious center, contains an early Christian mural that highlights the transition from paganism to Christianity in the region. Together, these murals exemplify the artistic and spiritual evolution during the Byzantine period, contributing to Thessaloniki's designation as a UNESCO World Heritage site.

1 	\x07HOLY TWELVE  
APOSTLES CHURCH
One of the town’s oldest 
churches was built in 1310 – 
1314 under the sponsorship  
of Patriarch Nephon I. It used 
to be a katholicon [main church] 
of a monastery dedicated to 
Theotokos [Mother of God] as 
shown by the mural depicting 
Theotokos and the Founder, 
as well as by the iconography 
on the aisle with images of 
the Holy Virgin’s life. Out 
of the original monastery 
complex, -apart from the 
katholicon – there remain the

state buildings on this location 
(to create a civic centre);  
in 1966, however, excavations 
on the spot revealed the 
Ancient Roman Forum and  
the process was halted. In  
the centre of the square stands 
the imposing bust of Eleftherios 
Venizelos (1977, G. Pappas), 
who remained a prime minister 
of Greece for more than 12 
years during the period 1910 – 
1932. There are small copper 
workshops in the adjacent 
Chalkeon and Kleisouras 
Streets, and their business has 
been an ongoing tradition since 
the byzantine period.
1.4  Panagia [Virgin Mary] 
Chalkeon.
(see p. 9)
1.5  Bey Hamami.
It lies on the SE side of  
Plateia Dikastirion. This impressive 
edifice was built in 1444 and  
it is the country’s largest 
ottoman bath house, a multi-
domed construction with 
separate rooms for males and 
females, structured along two 
parallel ways. It is divided in 
three sections (cold, tepid 
and hot areas) and there is 
also a vaulted tank for heating 
water. It is widely known as the 
Paradise Baths and it went by 
that name until 1968. Right next 
to it there is a roman platform 
that is indicative of the ground 
level 2000 years ago.
1.6  Roman (Ancient) Forum
During the roman period, 
this 2-hectare area used to be 
the social and religious centre 
of the city. Construction was 
completed in two phases  
(in the mid-2nd and mid-  
3rd centuries AD) and it was 
gradually abandoned after the 
7th century. The NW section 
of', '

HISTORIC CENTRE (3)
that the place had been used 
by Christians as well, during 
the late Roman period. South 
of the passageway there 
were shops dating from the 
1st until the 13th century; the 
underground Museum of the 
Roman Forum (see p. 71) was 
built there as an extension. 
A 2nd - 4th c. AD Odeon [C] 
was found behind the well-
preserved eastern stoa. It  
has been restored and it is now 
used as a venue for cultural 
events. A mint and an archive 
office are right next to it. In the 
SE side, a round bath house 
[D] was unearthed which has 
been in use since the 1st c. BC. 
Parts of a colonnade, mosaic 
floors, marble stairs, a section 
of a stone-paved street, sewer 
pipes, silver coins, stone and 
marble sculptures were all 
found in this archaeological 
site. The forum is also where 
the “Enchanted Ones” (las 
Incantadas) were discovered, 
a two-storeyed colonnaded 
archway with Corinthian-order 
columns and pillars four of 
which have survived. They are 
decorated with figures in relief 
in their interior as well as their 
exterior side (“Stoa of the 
Statuettes”). It is estimated 
that the Stoa’s location was 
at the south entrance to the 
forum (from Egnatia Street);  
in 1864 the pillars were 
removed and escorted to their 
present location at the Louvre 
Museum (Paris) by E. Miller.

atmosphere, Bit Pazar (meaning 
Small Market place) is a spot

11	\x07BYZANTINE BATHS  
(KULE KAFE)
It is located on Romfei Sq. (see 
p. 43) in Ano Poli and it is the 
only surviving Byzantine bath 
house, a domed 13th c. building 
made of brick, which was 
open to the public until 1940.

UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
During the Ottoman period it 
was named Kule Hamam and 
was divided in two (male and 
female section).
12 	\x07HOSIOS DAVID  
(MONI LATOMOU)
Moni Latomou [Latomou 
Monastery] has a huge 
archaeological and historical 
value, since it is an early type 
of a cross-in-square domed 
church. Its construction dates 
back to the 5th or 6th c. and 
it is believed to have been 
built by Theodora, daughter 
of the Byzantine emperor 
Maximilianus, who had been 
baptised a Christian. The 
monastery was dedicated to 
Hosios David [Saint David] in 
1921. Especially noteworthy 
are the mosaic depictions 
on the ceiling which show 
the Vision of Ezekiel and 
are contemporary to the 
construction of the monastery; 
the later ones of the 12th, 13th 
and 14th c. are also great art 
specimens of the Komnenian 
period. There is a surviving 
minaret entrance built in the 
16th c. when the church was 
converted into a mosque. The', 'thex. 
In 1430 it was converted into 
a mosque and was named 
Kazancilar Camii.
3 	\x07
ACHEIROPOIITOS 
CHURCH
It was founded in the second 
half of the 5th c. on the site 
of the roman public baths 
and it was dedicated to 
Panagia (Virgin Mary). It is a 
three-aisled, timber-roofed 
basilica with a narthex and a 
gallery. The nave is separated 
by the side aisles with 
colonnades of Theodosian-
style pillars and impost 
capitals made of marble 
as is made the floor of the 
nave. The preserved mosaic 
decorations date to the 5th 
c. whereas the murals on the 
south aisle date to the 13th 
c. After the city was captured 
by the Turks, this was the 
first church to be turned into 
a mosque. In 1922-1923 it 
housed refugees from Asia 
Minor and in 1939 Christian 
worship was once again 
practiced in it.
4 	\x07
AGIA SOFIA CHURCH 
[or ΗAGIA SOPHIA]
It was built in the mid-7th c.  
on the ruins of a 5th c. basilica, 
as a copy of Hagia Sophia 
[Holy Wisdom of God] in 
Constantinople, and is one  
of the most important early-
3
2

1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
Christian monuments in the 
Orthodox world. It is a cross-
domed basilica and used to 
be the Metropolitan Church 
(Cathedral) until 1523 when it 
was converted into a mosque; 
it was restored to Christian 
worship after 1912.', ' [ROTONTA]
This impressive round building 
lies on the route connecting 
the triumphal arch of Galerius 
(Kamara, see p. 37) and the 
Palace of Galerius (see p. 29). 
It has a diameter of 24.5 m. 
and its gigantic dome is 30 
m. high. It was built in 306 
AD by Galerius, probably as a 
temple of Zeus or Kaveiros or 
as a mausoleum; in the 5th c. 
it was converted into a church 
dedicated to the Holy Bodiless 
Powers. The 5th c. outstanding 
preserved mosaics impress 
with their variety of themes, 
their naturalistic rendering, 
the colour diversity and the 
brilliance of the gold and 
silver tesserae. In 1591 it was 
turned into a mosque when a 
towering minaret was added, 
which survives today. In the 
square, next to Rotunda, lies 
the small church of Agios  
Georgios [St. George] whence 
the monument took its

7th walk: 
WEST OF THE CENTRE-STAVROUPOLI
inaugurated in 1962 (S. Molfesis, 
Th. Papagiannis). Its exterior 
side combines modern and 
classical elements with wings 
added on the sides. It connects 
Thessaloniki with the rest of 
Greece, the Balkans and Istanbul; 
it is also the bus terminus 
towards most of the city areas. 
This will be the location of the 
west metro line terminus under 
construction in Thessaloniki.
2.2  Old Railway Station.
It was built in 1894 near the 
harbour (Old Station Street) 
in the neoclassical style, 
and it gradually connected 
Thessaloniki with Skopje, 
Belgrade, Monastir and 
Constantinople (modern-day 
Istanbul). Today it', ' the year it was 
founded until the present day, 
the history of Thessaloniki is 
depicted through an array of 
multimedia applications, special 
structures, printed graphic 
design compositions and 
archaeological material. The 
exhibition is organised in seven 
thematic categories, each one 
occupying one floor, as follows: 
Space and Time (ground floor), 
Transformations (1st floor), 
Monuments and History (2nd 
floor), Homeland of the people 
(3rd floor), Along the trade 
routes (4th floor), Leisure and 
Culture (5th floor), Thessaloniki 
– Flavours (6th floor). The 
museum’s shop is located on 
the last floor.
JEWISH MUSEUM OF 
THESSALONIKI
It was created following 
an initiative of the Jewish 
Community of Thessaloniki  
to promote the Sephardic 
legacy in town, which dates  
as far back as the 15th c. It has 
been open to visitors since 
1997. It houses a Centre of 
Research and Study of the 
Jewish History in Thessaloniki, 
an extensive library and an 
Audiovisual Centre. Permanent 
exhibitions are divided in four 
categories, as follows:
• Jewish necropolis. 
(ground floor). Tombstones and 
stelae with epitaph inscriptions 
are on display, from the great 
Jewish necropolis which 
used to lie east of the city 
walls. Photographs show the 
cemetery as it was in 1914.
• Jewish history. (1st floor). 
It occupies the central area 
with a narrative of the Jewish 
presence in Thessaloniki up  
to World War II.
• Folk Art and Life. (1st 
floor). A large array of exhibits 
paints a vivid picture of the

was a large court surrounded

and workshops, as well as

Temples. Excavations

The earlier buildings date to

were added later. In the 
centre there was a peristyle 
surrounding the courtyard, 
a propylaeum, and the royal 
quarters were on the north side.
Eastern cemetery. It is 
located east of the town.

Archaeοlogical Museum. 
This modern museum is 
among the most interesting 
ones in Northern Greece. 
Exhibits are grouped in 5 
principal thematic categories: 
in the first one, exhibits  
relate to the daily life of  
the Pella residents (mosaics, 
wall decorations, objects  
of everyday use and so on);  
in the second one, the public 
life is depicted with finds 
mostly from the Agora area;  
in the third one, objects used 
in the temples are on display 
and information is given on  
the local religious practices;  
in the fourth one, there are 
finds from the cemeteries and 
in the fifth one, focus is placed 
on the architectural design and 
structuring of the palace, as 
well as on the life of Alexander 
the Great. An interesting film

1.1  Military Museum  
of the Balkan Wars.
It is located in Gefyra village, 
25km NW of Thessaloniki, and 
it is housed in the mansion 
of J. Modiano (1906, P. 
Arrigoni). This is where the 
Greek army headquarters were 
set up by Constantine, the 
then heir to the Greek throne, 
on October 24-27, 1912; 
the final negotiations with 
the Turks about surrendering 
Thessaloniki took place on that 
spot. Rare relics are on display 
such as maps, uniforms, arms, 
medals, documents, items of 
daily use, and so on,']

UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS Thessaloniki has been one of the first towns to know the Christian religion by the Apostle Paul; during the Byzantine period it used to be the second most important city of the empire (co-reigning city) after Constantinople. At that time (4th – 15th c.), Christian monuments and churches were constructed in the town, and these make up a diachronic typology with a decisive influence on the entire Byzantine world. The following early-Christian and Byzantine monuments of the town are considered to be excellent specimens of the Byzantine church-building and art, and for this reason UNESCO declared them to be World Heritage Monuments, in 1988. A tour across this unique open-air Byzantine museum is truly a special experience. 1 \x07HOLY TWELVE APOSTLES CHURCH One of the town’s oldest churches was built in 1310 – 1314 under the sponsorship of Patriarch Nephon I. It used to be a katholicon [main church] of a monastery dedicated to Theotokos [Mother of God] as shown by the mural depicting Theotokos and the Founder, as well as by the iconography on the aisle with images of the Holy Virgin’s life. response:
## Significance of the Early Christian Mural in the Roman Forum

The early Christian mural found in the Roman Forum is a significant artifact that reflects the religious and cultural transitions that occurred in Thessaloniki during the late Roman period. This mural, along with other remnants from the early Christian era, showcases the architectural and artistic influences that shaped the city as it evolved from a pagan society to one that embraced Christianity. The mural serves as a visual representation of the early Christian community's beliefs and practices, marking a pivotal moment in the city's history.

The Roman Forum itself was a central hub for social and religious activities in Thessaloniki during the Roman era. The presence of early Christian murals within this context indicates that the site continued to hold importance even as the religious landscape changed. This transition is further emphasized by the fact that the Forum was used by Christians during the late Roman period, suggesting a continuity of cultural significance despite the shift in religious practices [Data: Sources (6), Reports (316); Entities (797, 424, 2011)].

## Relationship to Christian Monuments in Thessaloniki

The early Christian mural is part of a broader network of Christian monuments in Thessaloniki, which includes various churches and structures that were built during the Byzantine period. These monuments, such as the Agia Sofia Church and the Holy Twelve Apostles Church, are recognized for their architectural significance and their role in the development of Byzantine art and culture. The early Christian mural contributes to this narrative by providing insight into the artistic styles and religious themes that were prevalent during the transition from paganism to Christianity in the region [Data: Entities (71, 424); Relationships (2396)].

Moreover, the early Christian mural's connection to the Roman Forum highlights the integration of Christian elements into existing Roman structures, showcasing how early Christians adapted and repurposed these sites for their own religious practices. This blending of architectural styles and religious iconography is a hallmark of Thessaloniki's rich historical tapestry, where layers of cultural influences coexist and interact [Data: Relationships (2397, 2396)].

In summary, the early Christian mural found in the Roman Forum is not only a significant artistic and historical artifact but also a crucial link in understanding the evolution of Christian monuments in Thessaloniki. It exemplifies the city's transition during a transformative period and underscores the importance of the Roman Forum as a site of both social and religious significance throughout history.
reference: The early Christian mural found in the Roman Forum is significant as it represents the transition of the city into a center of Christian faith during the Roman period. This mural, uncovered in a public storehouse, showcases the artistic expression of early Christianity. It relates to the Christian monuments in Thessaloniki, which were constructed during the Byzantine period and reflect the city's historical importance as one of the first towns to embrace Christianity, influenced by the Apostle Paul. Both the mural and the monuments highlight Thessaloniki's rich Christian heritage and its role in the spread of Christianity in the Byzantine world.

["<1-hop>

UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS Thessaloniki has been one of the first towns to know the Christian religion by the Apostle Paul; during the Byzantine period it used to be the second most important city of the empire (co-reigning city) after Constantinople. At that time (4th – 15th c.), Christian monuments and churches were constructed in the town, and these make up a diachronic typology with a decisive influence on the entire Byzantine world. The following early-Christian and Byzantine monuments of the town are considered to be excellent specimens of the Byzantine church-building and art, and for this reason UNESCO declared them to be World Heritage Monuments, in 1988. A tour across this unique open-air Byzantine museum is truly a special experience. 1 \x07HOLY TWELVE APOSTLES CHURCH One of the town’s oldest churches was built in 1310 – 1314 under the sponsorship of Patriarch Nephon I. It used to be a katholicon [main church] of a monastery dedicated to Theotokos [Mother of God] as shown by the mural depicting Theotokos and the Founder, as well as by the iconography on the aisle with images of the Holy Virgin’s life. Out of the original monastery complex, -apart from the katholicon – there remain the NIKIS NIKIS GERMANOU SVOLOU IASONIDOU TSIMISKI VAS. response:
## Significance of Christian Murals in Thessaloniki

Thessaloniki, a city rich in history, showcases its early Christian heritage through various significant sites, including the Holy Twelve Apostles Church and the Roman Forum. The murals found in these locations are not only artistic expressions but also vital components of the city's cultural and religious narrative.

### Holy Twelve Apostles Church

The Holy Twelve Apostles Church, built between 1310 and 1314, is one of the oldest churches in Thessaloniki. It was originally the main church of a monastery dedicated to Theotokos, and its murals depict important religious themes, including the life of the Virgin Mary and various saints. These artworks are significant as they reflect the Byzantine artistic style and the theological concepts prevalent during the period. The church itself is recognized as a World Heritage Monument by UNESCO, underscoring its importance in the context of early Christian architecture and art [Data: Entities (67); Relationships (63, 2395)].

The murals crafted in different stages from the 8th to the 11th centuries are notable features of the basilica, indicating a thematic relationship that enhances the overall experience of the site. This interconnectedness highlights the importance of preserving these artworks as they collectively represent the artistic evolution and cultural heritage of the region [Data: Reports (201); Entities (432)].

### Roman Forum

The Roman Forum, another significant site in Thessaloniki, also contributes to the understanding of the city's early Christian heritage. The forum served as a central public space during the Roman period, and its remnants, including early Christian walls and structures, illustrate the transition from paganism to Christianity in the region. The murals and architectural elements found here signify the adaptation of early Christian communities as they established their presence in a city that was once a hub of Roman culture [Data: Entities (1010); Relationships (1869)].

### Conclusion

In summary, the Christian murals in the Holy Twelve Apostles Church and the Roman Forum are crucial to understanding Thessaloniki's early Christian heritage. They not only represent the artistic and theological developments of the time but also serve as historical markers of the city's transition from a Roman stronghold to a center of early Christianity. The preservation of these sites and their artworks is essential for maintaining the cultural identity of Thessaloniki and its rich historical narrative [Data: Entities (0, 18); Relationships (20, 28)].
reference: The Christian murals found in Thessaloniki's Holy Twelve Apostles Church, which depict Theotokos and the Founder, highlight the church's role as a significant early Christian monument built during the Byzantine period. Similarly, the early Christian mural uncovered in the Roman Forum, which served as the social and religious center of the city, reflects the city's rich Christian heritage and its importance in the spread of Christianity during the early centuries. Together, these murals exemplify Thessaloniki's historical significance as one of the first towns to embrace Christianity, influenced by the Apostle Paul.

Eptapyrgio was built in the 12th 
c., presumably on an older 9th c. 
fortress and took this name as 
at first there were seven towers 
there. The current structure 
includes ten towers and a small 
street that goes around it. The 
north side used to be a part  
of the city’s Early Christian 
walls, whereas the towers  
on the south side were added 
during the Byzantine period. In 
1431, the Ottoman Turks made 
certain modifications to them, 
according to an inscription 
placed above the entrance. 
Circa 1890 the construction 
was changed in order to house

buildings were added on

outside area. In 1989, the

name – Yedi Kule, was housed

city of the empire (co-reigning

At that time (4th – 15th c.), 
Christian monuments and 
churches were constructed in 
the town, and these make up 
a diachronic typology with a 
decisive influence on the entire 
Byzantine world. The following 
early-Christian and Byzantine 
monuments of the town are 
considered to be excellent 
specimens of the Byzantine 
church-building and art, and 
for this reason UNESCO 
declared them to be World 
Heritage Monuments, in 1988. 
A tour across this unique 
open-air Byzantine museum  
is truly a special experience.
1 	\x07HOLY TWELVE  
APOSTLES CHURCH
One of the town’s oldest 
churches was built in 1310 – 
1314 under the sponsorship  
of Patriarch Nephon I. It used 
to be a katholicon [main church] 
of a monastery dedicated to 
Theotokos [Mother of God] as 
shown by the mural depicting 
Theotokos and the Founder, 
as well as by the iconography 
on the aisle with images of 
the Holy Virgin’s life. Out 
of the original monastery 
complex, -apart from the 
katholicon – there remain the

(Cathedral) until 1523 when it 
was converted into a mosque; 
it was restored to Christian

are an absolute must-see, 
particularly the ones on the

Ascension of Christ, as are 
the murals crafted in different

Agios Ioannis Prodromos [St.

from this point you will enter 
the early-Christian baptistery 
(catacomb) of Agia Sofia, built

5 	\x07TRANSFIGURATION OF 
THE SAVIOUR CHURCH 
[METAMORFOSI SOTIROS]
It is located on Egnatia Street 
(see p. 34) almost between 
Kamara (see p. 37) and the 
Palace of Galerius (see p. 29). 
Construction took place possibly 
around 1340 and it is a typical 
example of the transitional type 
in Byzantine church-building, 
found particularly in Macedonia. 
Fine depictions of the Ascension 
of Christ, the Prophets and the 
Divine Liturgy decorate the dome.

This impressive round building

(KULE KAFE)
It is located on Romfei Sq. (see 
p. 43) in Ano Poli and it is the 
only surviving Byzantine bath 
house, a domed 13th c. building 
made of brick, which was 
open to the public until 1940.

12 	\x07HOSIOS DAVID  
(MONI LATOMOU)
Moni Latomou [Latomou 
Monastery] has a huge 
archaeological and historical 
value, since it is an early type 
of a cross-in-square domed 
church. Its construction dates 
back to the 5th or 6th c. and 
it is believed to have been 
built by Theodora, daughter 
of the Byzantine emperor 
Maximilianus, who had been 
baptised a Christian. The 
monastery was dedicated to 
Hosios David [Saint David] in 
1921. Especially noteworthy 
are the mosaic depictions 
on the ceiling which show 
the Vision of Ezekiel and 
are contemporary to the 
construction of the monastery; 
the later ones of the 12th, 13th 
and 14th c. are also great art 
specimens of the Komnenian 
period. There is a surviving 
minaret entrance built in the 
16th c. when the church was 
converted into a mosque. The', 'thex. 
In 1430 it was converted into 
a mosque and was named 
Kazancilar Camii.
3 	\x07
ACHEIROPOIITOS 
CHURCH
It was founded in the second 
half of the 5th c. on the site 
of the roman public baths 
and it was dedicated to 
Panagia (Virgin Mary). It is a 
three-aisled, timber-roofed 
basilica with a narthex and a 
gallery. The nave is separated 
by the side aisles with 
colonnades of Theodosian-
style pillars and impost 
capitals made of marble 
as is made the floor of the 
nave. The preserved mosaic 
decorations date to the 5th 
c. whereas the murals on the 
south aisle date to the 13th 
c. After the city was captured 
by the Turks, this was the 
first church to be turned into 
a mosque. In 1922-1923 it 
housed refugees from Asia 
Minor and in 1939 Christian 
worship was once again 
practiced in it.

the colour diversity and the 
brilliance of the gold and 
silver tesserae. In 1591 it was 
turned into a mosque when a 
towering minaret was added, 
which survives today. In the 
square, next to Rotunda, lies 
the small church of Agios

CHURCH
It is on Iasonidou st., pretty 
close to Rotunda. According 
to certain scholars, this 
was the main church of 
the Monastery of Kyr Isaac 
or Theotokos Perivleptos, 
founded by Jacob, the 
Metropolitan Bishop of 
Thessaloniki (1295-1314). 
It is a tetrastyle cross-in-
square domed church with a 
surrounding portico ending 
to the east in two chapels. 
During the Turkish Occupation 
it was changed into a mosque 
under the name Ishakiye 
Camii (the mosque of Isaac). 
Remaining murals date to 
the 13th – 14th c. and depict 
saints and prelates as well  
the Virgin Mary.
8 	\x07
AGIOS DIMITRIOS 
CHURCH
It is the best known Byzantine 
church of the town as Agios 
Dimitrios [St. Demetrius] is 
Thessaloniki’s patron saint. It 
was built during the 7th c. on 
the ruins of a 5th c. Basilica and 
in 1493 it was converted into 
a mosque. It was destroyed 
in 1917 by the fire but it was 
restored and reopened in 
1948. It is a five-aisle transept 
basilica with a women’s gallery 
and a narthex. The sculpted 
decorative motifs originate 
from the 5th c. basilica and 
other buildings and this 
explains their variety; equally 
interesting are the capitals (5th 
and 6th c.). The mosaics found 
on the west side date to the

2.1  Old Building of the 
Faculty of Philosophy.
This impressive construction 
took place in 1887, designed 
by V. Poselli. In 1908, two 
two-storey side wings were 
added and in 1927 the then 
newly established University 
of Thessaloniki (1925) was 
moved here from its former 
seat in Allatini Villa (see p. 
54). A number of schools of 
the Faculty of Philosophy of

building today.

3.2  Ancient Pydna.
It lies 43 km N of Dion and 
it was built in the 8th – 7th c. 
BC. During the 4th c. BC the 
Macedon king Philip II made 
Pydna the administrative 
centre of the district. In 168 
BC, Roman troops defeated 
the Macedonian army near 
the town, and that meant 
the beginning of Roman rule 
in Macedonia. Gradually the 
town went into decline and 
was successively occupied by 
Bulgarians, western Europeans 
and Turks, and got eventually 
deserted in the 15th c. 
Excavations have unearthed 
109

92
DAY EXCURSIONS
a neolithic settlement which 
is considered to have been 
the largest in the Hellenic 
area, a cemetery, two early-
Christian basilicas (4th and 
6th c.) and a 10th c. basilica 
with remarkable mosaics and 
murals.
How to get there.  
Dion is situated 87 km SW 
of Thessaloniki. Follow the 
national road to Athens and 
then the signs to Katerini and 
Dion. Alternatively, take the 
coach to Katerini (Pieria district) 
and then the local bus to Dion.
4 	PETRALONA CAVE
It was discovered in 1959, 
by accident, in the western 
part of Halkidiki. It is 1,500 
m. long (a 400 m. section is 
open to visitors); the chambers, 
the stalagtite and stalagmite 
formations within are very 
interesting. The location 
became universally known 
when an array of prehistoric 
items was found in the interior 
(fossil tree leaves,', 'ero, the Roman orator 
becomes a resident. 
 42 BC:	
Thessaloniki is declared  
a “free town” (civitas libera).
 50 BC:	
Apostle Paul’s first visit  
to the town. He came back 
seven years later. 
 Late 3rd – early 4th c. AD:	
Becomes the seat of  
the eastern section of the 
Roman Empire [according  
to the system of Tetrarchia – 
(meaning “leadership of four 
men”)] under ceasar Galerius 
Maximianus.
 323 BC:	
Constantine, the first 
emperor of Byzantium settles 
in town in order to wage war 
on Licinius.
 Late 4th AD:	
The town becomes  
the administrative centre  
of Macedonia; Byzantine 
emperor Theodosius builds  
the fortifications of Thessaloniki. 
 5th - 12th c.:	
Raids by Goths, Persians, 
Arabs, Turks and Bulgarians. 
The town is spared destruction 
thanks to its massive walls. 
 1185:	
The Norsemen occupy 
Thessaloniki.
 1224:	
After the 20-year Frankish 
domination of Thessaloniki, 
the town is taken by Theodore 
Komnenos Doukas and is 
declared the capital of the 
Despotate of Epirus.
 1300-1430:	
The golden age of the 
town involves great financial, 
social and intellectual growth. 
Some of the most significant 
monuments, built at that time, 
still stand today.
 1342-1349:	
The Zealot Movement 
prevails as a reaction to 
medieval hegemonism  
and the reign “by the grace  
of God”.
 1423:	
The town surrenders']

UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS Thessaloniki has been one of the first towns to know the Christian religion by the Apostle Paul; during the Byzantine period it used to be the second most important city of the empire (co-reigning city) after Constantinople. At that time (4th – 15th c.), Christian monuments and churches were constructed in the town, and these make up a diachronic typology with a decisive influence on the entire Byzantine world. The following early-Christian and Byzantine monuments of the town are considered to be excellent specimens of the Byzantine church-building and art, and for this reason UNESCO declared them to be World Heritage Monuments, in 1988. A tour across this unique open-air Byzantine museum is truly a special experience. 1 \x07HOLY TWELVE APOSTLES CHURCH One of the town’s oldest churches was built in 1310 – 1314 under the sponsorship of Patriarch Nephon I. It used to be a katholicon [main church] of a monastery dedicated to Theotokos [Mother of God] as shown by the mural depicting Theotokos and the Founder, as well as by the iconography on the aisle with images of the Holy Virgin’s life. ## Significance of Christian Murals in Thessaloniki's Byzantine Monuments

Christian murals are a vital aspect of Thessaloniki's rich Byzantine heritage, serving not only as artistic expressions but also as reflections of the religious and cultural practices of the time. In the context of significant sites such as the Holy Twelve Apostles Church and the Roman Forum, these murals provide insight into the historical and spiritual narratives that shaped the region.

### The Holy Twelve Apostles Church

The Holy Twelve Apostles Church, built between 1310 and 1314, is one of the oldest churches in Thessaloniki and showcases remarkable murals that depict various religious scenes. These murals are integral to the church's identity, illustrating the life of the Virgin Mary and other significant Christian events. The artistic style and themes of the murals reflect the Byzantine tradition, emphasizing the church's role as a center of worship and community identity [Data: Reports (160); Entities (67, 1280)].

The murals in the Holy Twelve Apostles Church are not merely decorative; they serve as a didactic tool, conveying theological messages and reinforcing the beliefs of the congregation. This aligns with the broader Byzantine practice of using art to educate and inspire the faithful, making the church a living testament to the era's religious fervor and artistic achievement [Data: Relationships (65, 2395)].

### The Roman Forum

In contrast, the Roman Forum, which served as a public space in ancient Thessaloniki, also features remnants of early Christian murals that highlight the transition from paganism to Christianity in the region. These murals, found in the context of the forum's architectural remains, illustrate the integration of Christian themes into public life, marking a significant cultural shift during the Byzantine period [Data: Sources (139)].

The presence of Christian murals in the Roman Forum signifies the evolving identity of Thessaloniki as it embraced Christianity, showcasing how public spaces were transformed to reflect the new religious landscape. This transformation is crucial for understanding the broader implications of Christian art in shaping community values and social structures during the Byzantine era [Data: Relationships (1869)].

### Conclusion

In summary, Christian murals in Thessaloniki, particularly in the Holy Twelve Apostles Church and the Roman Forum, hold profound significance. They are not only artistic masterpieces but also vital historical documents that narrate the spiritual journey of the city. These murals encapsulate the essence of Byzantine culture, illustrating the interplay between faith, art, and community identity during a transformative period in Thessaloniki's history [Data: Entities (67, 1280); Relationships (2395, 1869)].
reference: Christian murals in Thessaloniki are significant as they reflect the city's rich Byzantine heritage and its early adoption of Christianity. The Holy Twelve Apostles Church, built between 1310 and 1314, features a mural depicting Theotokos, showcasing the church's dedication to the Mother of God and its role in the Byzantine religious landscape. Additionally, the Roman Forum, which served as a social and religious center, contains an early Christian mural that highlights the transition from paganism to Christianity in the city. Together, these murals exemplify the artistic and spiritual evolution during the Byzantine period, contributing to Thessaloniki's designation as a UNESCO World Heritage site.

becomes a resident. 
 42 BC:	
Thessaloniki is declared  
a “free town” (civitas libera).
 50 BC:	
Apostle Paul’s first visit  
to the town. He came back 
seven years later. 
 Late 3rd – early 4th c. AD:	
Becomes the seat of  
the eastern section of the 
Roman Empire [according  
to the system of Tetrarchia – 
(meaning “leadership of four 
men”)] under ceasar Galerius 
Maximianus.
 323 BC:	
Constantine, the first 
emperor of Byzantium settles 
in town in order to wage war 
on Licinius.
 Late 4th AD:	
The town becomes  
the administrative centre  
of Macedonia; Byzantine 
emperor Theodosius builds  
the fortifications of Thessaloniki. 
 5th - 12th c.:	
Raids by Goths, Persians, 
Arabs, Turks and Bulgarians. 
The town is spared destruction 
thanks to its massive walls. 
 1185:	
The Norsemen occupy 
Thessaloniki.
 1224:	
After the 20-year Frankish 
domination of Thessaloniki, 
the town is taken by Theodore 
Komnenos Doukas and is 
declared the capital of the 
Despotate of Epirus.
 1300-1430:	
The golden age of the 
town involves great financial, 
social and intellectual growth. 
Some of the most significant 
monuments, built at that time, 
still stand today.
 1342-1349:	
The Zealot Movement 
prevails as a reaction to 
medieval hegemonism  
and the reign “by the grace  
of God”.
 1423:	
The town surrenders']

UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS Thessaloniki has been one of the first towns to know the Christian religion by the Apostle Paul; during the Byzantine period it used to be the second most important city of the empire (co-reigning city) after Constantinople. At that time (4th – 15th c.), Christian monuments and churches were constructed in the town, and these make up a diachronic typology with a decisive influence on the entire Byzantine world. The following early-Christian and Byzantine monuments of the town are considered to be excellent specimens of the Byzantine church-building and art, and for this reason UNESCO declared them to be World Heritage Monuments, in 1988. A tour across this unique open-air Byzantine museum is truly a special experience. 1 \x07HOLY TWELVE APOSTLES CHURCH One of the town’s oldest churches was built in 1310 – 1314 under the sponsorship of Patriarch Nephon I. It used to be a katholicon [main church] of a monastery dedicated to Theotokos [Mother of God] as shown by the mural depicting Theotokos and the Founder, as well as by the iconography on the aisle with images of the Holy Virgin’s life. response:
## Early Christian Murals in Thessaloniki

Thessaloniki, a city rich in history, showcases a variety of early Christian murals that reflect its significant Christian heritage. Among the most notable sites are the remnants of early Christian churches and basilicas, which feature exquisite murals that date back to the 4th and 5th centuries AD. These murals are not only artistic expressions but also serve as historical documents that illustrate the religious and cultural transitions of the time.

### Key Sites and Their Significance

1. **Agios Dimitrios Church**: This church is one of the most renowned Byzantine churches in Thessaloniki, built on the ruins of a 5th-century basilica. The interior of Agios Dimitrios is adorned with beautiful mosaics and murals that depict various saints and biblical scenes, showcasing the artistic styles of the early Christian period. The church is dedicated to St. Demetrius, the patron saint of Thessaloniki, and serves as a vital link to the city's Christian identity [Data: Entities (439); Relationships (3)].

2. **Basilica of Saint George**: Although not as well-preserved as Agios Dimitrios, the Basilica of Saint George contains remnants of early Christian murals that reflect the architectural and artistic trends of the time. These murals often depict scenes from the life of Christ and the Virgin Mary, emphasizing the central role of these figures in early Christian worship.

3. **Early Christian Walls**: The remnants of the Early Christian Walls, constructed between 365-380 AD, also provide insight into the city's early Christian architecture. While primarily defensive structures, they are indicative of the city's growth as a Christian center during this period [Data: Entities (1010); Relationships (2)].

### Cultural and Historical Context

The early Christian murals in Thessaloniki are significant as they represent the city's transition from a pagan to a Christian society. Following the Edict of Milan in 313 AD, which granted religious tolerance to Christians, Thessaloniki became a pivotal center for Christianity in the region. The murals serve as a testament to the flourishing of Christian art and the establishment of a distinct Christian identity within the city.

These artworks not only reflect the theological themes of the time but also illustrate the socio-political changes occurring in Thessaloniki as it evolved into a major Christian hub. The presence of these murals contributes to the understanding of Thessaloniki's rich Christian heritage and its role in the broader narrative of early Christianity in the Byzantine Empire.

In summary, the early Christian murals found in Thessaloniki are integral to the city's cultural and religious landscape, providing a glimpse into its historical significance as a center of early Christian art and architecture. The preservation of these murals allows visitors and scholars alike to appreciate the depth of Thessaloniki's Christian heritage [Data: Reports (316), Entities (0, 7, 18); Relationships (399, +more)].
reference: In Thessaloniki, early Christian murals can be found in significant monuments such as the Holy Twelve Apostles Church, which features a mural depicting Theotokos and the Founder, reflecting the city's deep Christian heritage established by the Apostle Paul. Additionally, the Roman Forum contains a valuable early Christian mural uncovered in the double underground Cryptoporticus, showcasing the city's role as a social and religious center during the Roman period. These murals highlight Thessaloniki's historical significance as a hub of Christian art and architecture.
